Nobbs created Reggie Perrin after the BBC asked him to submit an idea for a half hour play about social problems, as part of a series. His pitch – about a man driven mad by his commute – was rejected. But Nobbs turned the idea into a novel. The original draft had a slightly different twist – the early incarnation of Perrin ended up in a psychiatric home rather than faking his own death. In his autobiography, Nobbs recalled some inspirations, including an article he’d read about the tedious process that a jam manufacturer went through to create a new flavour; and a mortgage company advert with a nauseatingly smug family in matching outfits. “In my mind this was a key image for the world against which Reggie was rebelling,” wrote Nobbs. Also, as a child, Nobbs would get the train to school, surrounded each morning by the type of commuters that Reginald Perrin was doomed to become – pinstriped suits, umbrellas, newspapers. Nobbs wanted   for the role of Perrin, and Barker was certainly a fan. “I laughed two hundred and eighty-seven times and cried twice,” said Barker about reading Nobbs’s book. “I would love to play Reggie Perrin in a film. I still feel I am Reggie Perrin as I walk about. What a beautiful book.” Granada offered to make it as a two-part drama with Barker, but Nobbs’s agent insisted it should be a sitcom at the BBC. “I couldn’t believe my ears,” said Nobbs. “My novel a sit-com!” When Nobbs went for a meeting with Jimmy Gilbert, the Head of Comedy at the BBC, Gilbert asked if he had anyone in mind for the role of Reggie Perrin. “Yes, Ronnie Barker,” said Nobbs. Gilbert replied: “Very good. Leonard Rossiter it is.” Rossiter had become a star from his performance as Rigsby, the lecherous, misery-guts landlord in the hit ITV sitcom Rising Damp. Nobbs admitted that he was disappointed at first but soon changed his mind. “Suddenly I felt that he might be irresistible in The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin,” Nobbs wrote about Rossiter. The first series began broadcasting on September 8, 1976. Watched now, it’s still joyously unusual – not to mention strangely relatable, as Reggie tries to escape the monotonous, middle class existence which closes in on him. Each morning he kisses his wife at the door; each morning he walks the same streets of the “Poets Estate” – through Coleridge Close, Tennyson Avenue, and Wordsworth Drive; and each day suffers the banality of a so-called-life inside Sunshine Desserts. The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin perfectly captures 1970s Britain, with its drab interiors, processed puddings, and manufacturing decline – even the Sunshine Desserts sign is crumbling from above the door, one letter at a time. Perrin is plagued by visions: not just his mother-in-law as a hippo, but him flashing at a neighbour on his way to work, torturing his boss on a rack, and rapturous trysts with his secretary Joan (Corrie’s Sue Nicholls). The fractured state of Reggie’s mind shows with his increasingly outlandish excuses for being late into the office every day: “Eleven minutes late, somebody had stolen the lines at Surbiton… Seventeen minutes late, water seeping through the cables at Effingham Junction – there was a lot of Effingham and a good deal of Blindingham… Twenty-two minutes late, escaped puma, Chessington North.” Indeed, seen from Reggie’s perspective, the real world is slightly skew whiff: there's a fellow commuter who blows his nose on various newspaper supplements; his brother-in-law Jimmy (the deadpan Geoffrey Palmer), forever dropping by to blag the contents of their fridge – “Bit of a cock-up on the catering front”; and a family trip to a safari park so infuriating that Reggie gets out of the car while in the lion park. (Nobbs recalled that while shooting the scenes at Longleat, a coachload of Welsh pensioners came into the area and excitedly photographed the lions – but the lions quickly revealed themselves to be BBC props men in costumes.) There’s humanity in Leonard Rossiter’s finely-tuned performance – a bundle of repression and desperation. According to Nobbs, Rossiter was a “perfectionist and not always easy to work with”. In the best episode, Reggie plans to have an affair with his secretary Joan while his wife’s away. It goes wrong when all of the family decide to pop round at the same time, forcing Reggie to keep his fancy woman hidden in the bedroom while he distracts everyone else, trying to keep them from going upstairs. In those scenes he’s possessed by a wild-eyed mania, stumbling over his words with rapid-fire, precision-perfect delivery. “Leonard could express the anxieties Reggie was experiencing in every move, expression and word he uttered,” said Nobbs. "He could also combine pace with subtlety, which is very difficult. Most actors who try being subtle come across as slow, but not Leonard – he could rattle the lines out at a rate of knots while still retaining that degree of delicacy." You do have to admire Reggie’s gumption to reject modern life. There’s a sense of wish-fulfillment as he plunges into crack-pottery. In one sequence he dreams of pelting muck at his boss, the pompous C.J. (John Barron); in the real world, he can’t suppress what he really thinks any longer. “I can’t be bothered with this,” he says during a sales meeting. “Life’s too short.”  Eventually, Perrin fakes his own death by leaving his clothes on a beach in Dorset and heading into the sea. He then switches between various identities, with daft wigs and buck teeth. But he misses his family and returns home in the guise of bearded alter-ego Martin Wellbourne, and remarries Elizabeth. As Martin he even attends his own memorial service – a deceptively dark, psychologically troubling scenario. The show is not entirely free of old school sitcom fare. There’s rude humour, of course – the kind that seemed to make Seventies studio audiences howl saucily, such as a recurring joke about chairs that make a whoopee cushion noise whenever sat on. That gag actually came from Nobbs’s first visit to Jimmy Gilbert’s office. His chair sounded “like a cross between a muffled fart and an elderly toad’s sigh of satisfaction,” said Nobbs. There are plenty of catchphrases. too The likes of “Great!” and “Super!” soon get old – the respective catchphrases of junior yes men Tony and David (Trevor Adams and Bruce Bould) – but C.J.’s patented “I didn’t get to where I am today…” is funny every time, and delightfully nonsensical. (See: “I didn't get where I am today without knowing a real winner when I see one”; “I didn't get where I am today by indulging in hanky panky”; and “I didn't get where I am today by having green frogs thrust down my crotch”.) Nobbs knew the show was a hit when he heard some businessmen bantering in a hotel lobby. “I’m going up the stairs,” he heard one of them say. “I didn’t get where I am today by waiting for lifts.” “Great,” another man replied. “Super,” said the other. In 1977, Nobbs published a follow-up novel, The Return of Reginald Perrin. He had to – Leonard Rossiter would agree to a second series only if Nobbs wrote a second book too. He believed that’s where the depth of the show came from. In the second series, Perrin returns to his real identity – his wife Elizabeth seems surprisingly fine with the whole charade – and tries to have one more laugh at society’s expense by opening a shop called Grot, which proudly sells useless, overpriced rubbish. But the business is a huge success, which sees Reggie trapped in the rat race once again and trying – but failing – to sabotage his own business empire. He contemplates faking his death once again, but this time with Elizabeth. A third series followed in 1978 – based on book No. 3, The Better World of Reginald Perrin – in which Reggie and Elizabeth try to set up a utopia-like community for middle-class middle-aged people. It’s the weakest series – not particularly good, in fact. An episode in which Reggie and his gang try to scare the neighbours by wearing blackface will give BBC Four some pause for thought. A fourth series was made in 1996, but this time without Rossiter, who died in 1984. In The Legacy of Reginald Perrin, his friends and family each inherited £1 million, on the condition they “do something totally and utterly absurd”. Martin Clunes also played the character in a 2009 revival. The first series stands up as Reggie Perrin's finest few hours. It's even profound – a cynical assessment of an ordinary life. No matter what he does, he’s never happy. As Reginald Perrin says himself: “Sheer bliss isn’t enough!”

heading: How to watch this year’s Bafta-nominated films
subheading: Keen to catch Nomadland, Promising Young Woman, Rocks or The Father? Here's our guide to the online streamers and cinema release dates
author: Marianka Swain
article: The   is, says our film critic,  , properly showcasing British talent as well as honouring the best work from the international scene. Of course,   in the UK until May 17. So, where and how can you see all these great movies?   Chloé Zhao’s  , about America’s drifters, is the joint leader with seven nominations, including nods for Best Film, Best Director and Frances McDormand for Best Actress. Nomadland premieres on Disney+ (£7.99 a month) on April 30, and will be in UK cinemas when they reopen - so likely mid May. The other film boasting seven nominations is Sarah Gavron’s  , with well-deserved nods for its talented newcomers - Bukky Bakray and Kosar Ali. Rocks had a modest run in cinemas last year, and is now available on Netflix (from £5.99 a month), but is surely due another theatrical release too. The film adaptation of Florian Zeller’s  , about a man suffering from dementia, is up for six awards, including Best Film and Best Actor for Anthony Hopkins. Although it premiered at Sundance over a year ago, it hasn’t yet been released in UK cinemas, but good news: it’s due out on June 11.  Emerald Fennell’s dark-comedy rape revenge   has been an awards season talking point - boosted by star   with a Variety film reviewer. It’s up for six awards, including Best Film, and UK viewers can finally see it when it comes to Sky Cinema and streaming service NOW on April 16.  about the finding of Sutton Hoo in 1939 - again starring Mulligan, this time alongside Ralph Fiennes - has five nominations, its best bet probably Moira Buffini’s screenplay. The Dig had a limited cinema release in January and is now available on Netflix, but don’t rule out a return to the big screen.  of a South Korean family pursuing the American dream has six nods - including Best Director, and Best Supporting Actor for the adorable Alan Kim. It will have an initial on demand and virtual cinema release via minari.film from April 2, and will hopefully hit cinemas when they reopen. Hollywood lore always does well in awards season, and   about the writer of Citizen Kane, Herman J Mankiewicz, is no exception. It’s up for six Baftas (although misses out on some of the big ones, like Best Film and Best Director), and you can see it now on Netflix. Rose Glasss’s   sees Morfydd Clark’s Maud’s devout Catholic nurse tending to Jennifer Ehle’s terminally ill patient. It’s up for Outstanding British Film and Outstanding Debut, and following, its cinema release last October, is now available on Blu-ray and DVD, or to rent from Amazon Prime (£7.99 a month subscription, or £4.49 for a one-off rental). A crack ensemble cast revisits the story of the anti-Vietnam War protestors who were prosecuted following the riots at the National Democratic Convention in 1968.   has three nominations, including for Best Film and Aaron Sorkin’s screenplay, and is available to watch on Netflix. A surprisingly strong showing for this  , which is also inspired by true events - in this case, Mohamedou Ould Salahi being held for 14 years without charge at Guantanamo Bay. Its five nominations include Best Film, and UK viewers can see it via video on demand on Amazon Prime from April 1.  is the Danish entry for this year’s Oscars, and also picks up four nominations here, including Best Actor for Mads Mikkelsen. He plays a depressed teacher who tests out a theory that constant, low-level drinking can improve your life. It played at the London Film Festival, and is due to hit cinemas on June 25. Daniel Kaluuya has already won a Golden Globe for his performance as Fred Hampton, the Black Panther member betrayed by an FBI informant - although many are puzzled about why he’s in the Best Supporting Actor category.   is up for four Baftas total, and is available on video on demand via BFI Player and others from March 11.  is an unflinching portrait of loss, featuring a 24-minute scene of a home birth ending in tragedy. The Crown’s Vanessa Kirby scores a nomination for her extraordinary lead performance, and it’s available to watch now on Netflix. The likely winner for Best Animated Film - and also up for Best Sound and Best Original Score - is   about a jazz musician trying to reunite his body and soul, as well as figuring out his purpose in life. It premiered exclusively on Disney+ on Christmas Day 2020, and is still available on the streamer. The   of August Wilson’s stage play - about the real-life blues singer Ma Rainey - is up for three awards, including Best Actor for the late, great   as ambitious trumpeter Levee. You can catch in now on Netflix. Riz Ahmed plays a hard rock drummer and recovering addict who loses his hearing in this Darius Marder drama. He’s up for Best Actor, and the film has four nominations total. UK viewers can see it on Amazon Prime from April 12, and it will be in cinemas when they reopen, so likely May 17. Probably best known for “that scene” with Trump’s lawyer Rudy Giuliani, Sacha Baron Cohen’s   also proved a breakout role for Maria Bakalova, who played his fictional daughter Tutar, and she picks up a nomination here. You can watch it now (from behind a cushion) on Amazon Prime. The   has scored four nominations - although none for Hanks himself, playing a former Confederate officer who makes a living reading out newspapers, and who must return a young girl to her family. It’s on Netflix now. Spike Lee’s   - about four Vietnam War veterans in search of both their missing squad leader and their buried treasure - has one Bafta nod: Clarke Peters for Best Supporting Actor. It’s available to watch now on Netflix.  This propulsive adaptation of Aaravind Adiga’s Booker Prize-winning novel - which highlights inequality and corruption - sees Balram escaping from his poor Indian village by becoming the local landlord’s chauffeur. It’s nominated for its screenplay and Adarsh Gourav as Best Actor, and you can find it now on Netflix. Jasmila Žbanić is a surprise entrant in the Best Director category, and her Bosnian war drama - set during the Srebenica massacre of 1995 - is also up for Best Film Not In The English Language. It’s available on Curzon Home Video (£9.99 for non-members). Australian director Shannon Murphy is nominated for this off-kilter, powerfully acted   (based on Rita Kalnejais’ stage play). It’s about a teenage cancer sufferer - played by Eliza Scanlen - who falls in love with a drug addict, and you can watch it now on Netflix. Regina King directs the   of Kemp Powers’ stage play, about a fictional meeting between Malcolm X, Muhammad Ali, Jim Brown and Sam Cooke. Leslie Odom Jr (already a Tony winner for musical Hamilton) is nominated for Best Supporting Actor for playing Cooke, and it’s available now on Amazon Prime. Four nominations for  , an Irish crime drama about a former boxer who works as an enforcer for a criminal family. The film pivoted to a digital release last year, and is available on the likes of Amazon and iTunes (for both, £3.49 to rent), as well as BFI Player (£4.50 to rent).  Alfre Woodward has received a Best Actress nomination for playing a warden in a maximum security prison, whose growing concerns about the death penalty lead to a crisis of faith.   is available now on Amazon Prime. Kate Winslet and Saoirse Ronan star in this  , which is loosely inspired by the life of British palaeontologist Mary Anning, and has scored a Bafta nomination for its costume design. The current UK release date is March 26, presumably on a streaming platform since cinemas will still be closed.  Remi Weekes’s topical horror film sees a refugee couple from South Sudan trying to make a new life in an English town - only to discover that their troubles are just beginning. His House has three nods, including Outstanding British Film and Outstanding Debut for Weekes, and you can catch it now on Netflix. Christopher Nolan’s time-twisting, head-spinning   was one of the major new cinema releases post-lockdown in 2020, but it hasn’t proved the awards juggernaut some predicted. Still, it gets a nod here for its impressive visual effects, and it’s available now on Amazon Prime. Likewise, Autumn de Wilde’s   (with a screenplay by Eleanor Catton) has only picked up one nomination here, for Best Costume Design. But its charming cast features Anya Taylor-Joy, Johnny Flynn, Josh O’Connor and Bill Nighy, and you can find it now on Amazon Prime. Another Tom Hanks entry - this time an   based on C. S. Forester’s novel The Good Shepherd, about a US Navy commander defending merchant ships under attack by German U-boats. It’s nominated for its sound and visual effects, and is available to watch on Apple TV+ (£4.99 a month).

heading: When Bond went Blaxploitation: Yaphet Kotto’s problem with Live And Let Die
subheading: The late actor's role as the Bond franchise's first black villain was revolutionary – a little too revolutionary for some
author: Tristram Fane Saunders
article: For  ’s first appearance as   in 1973, MGM went out of their way to make him as unlike his predecessor as possible. This suave new spy drank gin-and-tonics (not vodka martinis), smoked cigars (not cigarettes), and – in a feat zanier than anything ever attempted by Sean Connery – used killer reptiles as stepping stones. In Live and Let Die’s most famous set-piece, 007 runs across the backs of a line of crocodiles. It wasn’t the real 007, but they were certainly real crocs. While scouting for locations in Jamaica’s Montego Bay, the producers had driven past a curious sign: “Trespassers will be eaten”. It marked the entrance to a crocodile farm owned by a man called Ross Kananga. The crew decided to give Kananga a role as Moore’s stunt double for a scene at his ranch, rather than risk a member of their cast or crew to the critters’ snapping jaws. Wearing a pair of crocodile-skin shoes (a joke suggested by Moore), Kananga completed the death-defying dash in just five takes. The producers were so impressed by Kananga that appropriated his name for the film's chief villain, played by the black actor Yaphet Kotto – in another sign that this wasn't Connery's 007, he would be the first black Bond villain. But the role proved to be a mixed blessing for Kotto, who has died at the age of 81. Although Bond was eventually good for his career and led to roles in Alien and Raid on Entebbe, he later complained of feeling sidelined on-set and was all but shut out of the film's publicity campaign. "The producers did not want to promote me in the film," he said in 2007. "In fact, I found out that Time magazine and Newsweek were interviewing the rest of the cast. I went to [producer] Harry Saltzman and said, 'Why wasn't I included?' 'We were afraid that there's never been a black villain before. We don't want people to think stuff.' So they didn't promote me." The producers, essentially, feared a backlash if the public found out that their villain was black. The making of the film itself was just as problematic, with not every scene going as smoothly as the crocodile hopping. It took no fewer than 29 takes to film the moment when Bond uses his magnetic watch to unzip a dress worn by buxom Italian agent Miss Caruso (Madeline Smith). This might explain why their love-scene is one of the more stilted encounters in the Bond canon, but the lengthy shoot wasn’t the only mood-killer. According to Smith, Moore’s wife Luisa Mattioli insisted on supervising the scene, keeping a chilly eye on her to make sure there was absolutely no funny business. Moore would hardly have been in the mood, anyway: during the shoot, he was hospitalised with a painful bout of kidney stones. He was put on an a new medication to deal with them, but the pills left him with a woozy head – and bright blue urine. “I was still zonked out and in unfamiliar surroundings, so when I got up for a pee at two in the morning, I opened what I thought was the bathroom door when it was the wardrobe and relieved myself,” he told the Mail. “'The next morning I discovered my mistake when I found my lovely clothes had turned various shades of patchy blue!” Elsewhere, filming was beset by problems. One actor was bitten by a snake, which escaped his grasp and slithered over defenceless actress Jane Seymour (who was tied between two bedposts at the time) before it was recaptured. In filming a thrilling water-chase Moore’s boat veered out of control and crashed through a boathouse wall, twisting his knee and cracking his teeth. “There I was, a fearless 007, hobbling on a cane to my boat and then pretending to be indestructible for the cameras," he recalled in his autobiography. “Who says I can't act?” The actor also managed to keep his cool when faced with a trapdoor that looked likely to decapitate anyone who used it. But only after he insisted that the door’s designer John Wardley should test it out first. Wardley remembered the scene in an interview with the Huffington Post’s Mike Peake: “[What] proved to me what a cool guy Roger Moore was, is a scene in a bar called the Fillet of Soul run by the villains. There is a table that disappears into the ground once Bond sits at it. This mechanism was quite a sturdy piece of equipment and the director insisted that the sliding floor should come across rapidly as the table disappears. It whistled across your forehead and slammed shut. We designed this contraption and all in all there was about three tons of steel in it. “The director said to Moore, ‘Whatever you do, you must not flinch’, at which point Moore turned to me and said, ‘I’ll do one take – but I want to see him’, pointing at me, ‘do it first.’ So I did, and it was pretty frightening. He then did it, and he did not bat an eyelid.” Although the risky action sequences and rogue reptiles caused a headache for producers, the real snake in the grass turned out to be the film’s casting. With the film’s action moving between New York's Harlem, Louisiana and the Caribbean, Live and Let Die was the franchise’s attempt to cash in on the burgeoning Blaxploitation genre, following the recent success of Shaft (1971) and Super Fly (1972). It was intended to be a bold departure from previous Bond films, an idea winked at in the script. In one scene, Moore starts to introduce himself with Connery’s catchphrase (“My name is…”) only to be cut off by Kotto's Harlem gangster and master of disguise Mr Big, aka Dr Kananga: “Names is for tombstones, baby.” As well as the franchise’s first major black villain, the film also starred – to the distaste of a few bigoted audience members in America’s Deep South – its first black Bond girl. “As Bond, I make love to Rosie Carver, played by beautiful black actress Gloria Hendry, and Luisa [Mattioli] has learned from certain Louisiana ladies that if there is a scene like that they won’t go to see the picture,” Moore wrote in his 1973 James Bond Diary (now sadly out of print). He continued: “I personally don’t give a damn and it makes me all the more determined to play the scene.” Regardless of Moore’s views, many of the choices made during the production now seem shockingly insensitive. The original script featured a major role for an African-American actress as Bond’s main love interest: Obeah mystic and tarot-card reader Solitaire. At one point Diana Ross was among the stars considered for the part. But the producers got cold feet, recasting the role at the last minute – perhaps over concerns about the worldwide box office. At the time, any films depicting an interracial relationship were still banned in several territories, including Japan and South Africa. “While filming somewhere in New York City or New Orleans, they decided that it was too risky to have a black woman end up with James Bond,” Hendry said in a 2004 interview. “Therefore, the [smaller, supporting] role of Rosie Carver was switched to black, and the role of Solitaire was switched to white. That is where I came in.” The producers didn’t feel it was worth their time to find a realistic stunt double for Hendry, and resorted to the controversial practice of  . For one bedroom scene, “They ended up having a white British gentleman in brown makeup with a dress and an Afro wig,” Hendry has recalled. Yaphet Kotto, meanwhile, was not invited to the premiere and and celebrated the film's release with friends in a Harlem bar. “They were afraid the public would react negatively to a black villain so they didn’t play my character up,” he told the Big Issue in 2015. “That hurt me a lot, man. I went through a lot of goddamn emotional hell because they were afraid people would be angry that a black guy was not being Sidney Poitier. I was the opposite of everything he created.” Earlier, Kotto had claimed the producers essentially "set me up" and portrayed him as a rabble-rouser: "One of the actors raised a clenched fist, saluting me, so I raised my clenched fist, and a photographer swiveled around and said, 'You're a militant SOB' and took my picture and gave that to the producers. I had promised Dr. King – I was with him at a couple of demonstrations – that I would never do anything militant. So they had me pegged wrong." Although the film’s racial politics can look seriously dated today (not to mention its villain's bizarre, flatulent death scene), Kotto felt that having such a formidable black character in a world-straddling franchise “would open up the doors for others – and it worked". The actor had some personal experience to prove it: he was later offered the role of Captain Picard in Star Trek, but turned it down. He was less positive about his co-star. "I have nothing to say about Roger Moore," he told an interviewer in 2007. "He said in his book – I don't know if I read it in there, but one of my secretaries told me – he said, 'Yaphet had a chip on his shoulder.' What is this dude talking about? What is his problem? I mind my business, do my job. If he said that, he had no right to because he doesn't know me that well." But if any part of the Bond series's muddled foray into Blaxploitation was a success, Kotto has said, it's less due to Roger Moore than to the charismatic Kananga: “a guy who is completely together – almost as together as James Bond himself. He was a hero!”

heading: Oscars 2021: When are the 93rd Academy Awards and how to watch the ceremony live in the UK
subheading: Hollywood's big night is going ahead – but it's not quite the Oscars as normal. Here's everything we know so far
author: Marianka Swain
article: This year’s rather unusual film awards season culminates with Oscars in late April. But what can we expect from the 2021 Academy Awards - and how much will Covid change Hollywood’s big night?  The ceremony for the   takes place on April 25, airing live on US TV station ABC at 8pm Eastern Daylight Time (midnight UK time). It’s a delay from its usual February date. Sky Cinema will air the event in full on its sub-channel Sky Cinema Oscars, followed by a highlights reel on Sky One. The Sky coverage will also be streamed online through Now TV. Existing Sky TV customers can sign up Sky Cinema for £11 a month, or you can pay £11.99 a month for Now TV’s Sky Cinema Pass. Although there’s a handy loophole for the latter: you can get a seven-day free trial. The ceremony will be held outdoors in a courtyard at downtown railway hub Union Station in Los Angeles. According to veteran Oscars director Glenn Weiss and first-time producers Jesse Collins, Stacey Sher and   (an apt choice: the director of  ), there will also be some “additional show elements” coming live from the Dolby Theatre – which usually hosts the Oscars ceremony. In a joint statement, the producers stressed that they want the telecast to “look like a movie, not a television show.” So, expect some ambitious elements – perhaps musical performances or comic skits from the Dolby. The Oscars haven’t had a host for the past two years; the last host was  . It looks like there will not be a host in 2021 either, but instead a reliance on multiple awards presenters to keep the show on the road. In the main: yes. The producers are urging nominees to show up at what they call “an intimate, in-person event” - and no Zoom participation is allowed (avoiding the disasters of the  ). Only nominees, their guests and the presenters will be invited to this scaled-down Oscars. Organisers are also enlisting celebrities for video interviews to be taped ahead of time and broadcast during the show. We don’t yet know who the presenters are, although we’ll likely see the usual mix of A-list actors and directors, including winners from last year - like Joaquin Phoenix, Renée Zellwegger, Brad Pitt and Laura Dern.  The producers have said that they are treating the event like an active movie set. That means an on-site Covid safety team administering PCR tests, and lots of rules in place for those attending - presumably involving mask wearing and social distancing.  Fear not: the tearful, rambling, occasionally political and always OTT acceptance speeches are a go. However, the producers have urged winners to “read the room” and “tell a story”, rather than just listing off names, and to bear in mind that organisers are “aiming for a feeling of casual exchange and good humour.” Absolutely. While some awards shows have embraced lockdown fashion (i.e. pyjamas as daywear), the Academy Awards are holding firm. The dress code, per the producers, is “a fusion of Inspirational and Aspirational, which in actual words means formal is totally cool if you want to go there, but casual is really not.” In other words, ditch the hoodie and dust off that tux. Not as such. But there will be a 60-minute, pre-show virtual event from   (who won the Best Original Song Oscar last year for  ), raising money for his AIDS Foundation. Neil Patrick Harris will host, alongside John and David Furnish, with a stripped-back performance from Dua Lipa. The special will be on virtual platform Cisco Webex, streamed in the US on April 25 and elsewhere (including the UK) on April 26. You can purchase tickets via Ticketmaster. Vanity Fair is also going online with a charity event series to benefit the Motion Picture & Television Fund’s Covid relief efforts. Their Cocktail Hour Live will take place April 13-15, offering a mix of interviews, performances, panel discussions and cast reunions. A-listers confirmed include Serena Williams, Michael B Jordan, Gal Gadot, Glenn Close, and   nominee Amanda Seyfried. The awards honour films released between January 1 2000 and February 28 2021. The Academy’s board of governors voted to temporarily allow films that were first released via streaming services or video on demand to be eligible, if they were originally scheduled to have a theatrical release. That means films which haven’t yet been released in cinemas, due to Covid, are still considered. This year’s list of nominees has already made history. There are two women in the Best Director category:   for   and Emerald Fennell for  , with Zhao hotly tipped to win the award - as is Nomadland for Best Picture. There are also nine actors of colour nominated, including the first Asian-American up for Best Actor,  ’s Steven Yeun. We may well see a diverse list of winners, too, with the late   favourite to win a posthumous Best Actor Award for  , and Daniel Kaluuya leading the race for Best Supporting Actor for . Adding to a good haul for the Brits, we may well see Ferrell nab a Best Original Screenplay trophy and/or Sacha Baron Cohen take Best Adapted Screenplay for  , following their Writers Guild Awards wins. Also in the mix are David Fincher’s Mank, which picked up an impressive 10 Oscar nominations; The Father, starring Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman, with six nods; Aaron Sorkin’s  , with six; the Riz Ahmed-starring Sound of Metal, also with six; and Best Actress challenges from Andra Day in  , and Vanessa Kirby in  . And might the silly spoof   scoop Best Original Song? Stranger things have happened... Good news: we’ve got a   waiting for you, so you can get up to speed ahead of the ceremony and pick your own winners at home.

heading: Why Dick Van Dyke was the true marvel of WandaVision
subheading: The 95-year-old's pursuit of perfection has made him a living legend – and cost him dearly, Now he's an unsung hero of the Marvel Universe
author: Martin Chilton
article: “If someone from the UK sees me, they are on me like a pack of wolves,” joked  , who always accepted the mockery over his role in Mary Poppins with good grace, admitting he’d delivered “the most atrocious Cockney accent in the history of cinema”. Even so, the man who played Bert the chimney sweep remains indubitably popular. Paul Bettany, the London-born actor who plays Vision in  , said he drew on the American, one of his “favourite stars”, for inspiration in the hit Disney+ series. “I throw a little bit of Dick Van Dyke in there,” Bettany said of his accent playing the synthetic humanoid. WandaVision, the show based on Marvel Comics characters, has introduced a modern generation to the delights of the 95-year-old actor and singer, whose brilliant sitcom The Dick Van Dyke Show, which ran from 1961 to 1966, was a jewel of comedy writing and acting. The show, along with his contributions to popular films such as Chitty Chitty Bang Bang and Mary Poppins, forged Van Dyke’s reputation as an entertainment giant and one of the most likable stars ever to appear on television. Despite admitting that they had to explain WandaVision to Van Dyke, a man who “did not seem to be too fluent with the Marvel Cinematic Universe,” the show’s director Matt Shakman described his lunch with the veteran star as “one of the best afternoons of my life”. Shakman and Marvel President Kevin Feige picked his brains about his celebrated CBS series, and in turn appointed him as a consultant on WandaVision. “It was an opportunity to talk about how they made The Dick Van Dyke Show, which is one of the greatest television shows ever made. And it still works just as well today as it did back then. It’s a timeless classic,” Shakman told Looper. In the penultimate episode of the debut season of WandaVision, it is revealed that Wanda Maximoff’s Sokovian family were hooked on American sitcoms. We see her watching a clip from her favourite The Dick Van Dyke Show episode, one from 1963 called It May Look Like a Walnut. It had a science-fiction based plotline about body-snatching, tipping a nod to The Twilight Zone. The Dick Van Dyke Show’s creator Carl Reiner had to battle for that unusual episode to be made. “My partners didn’t want to do it,” he recalled. Van Dyke’s character Rob Petrie dreams that he may be the last remaining human, in a world ruled by an alien from the planet Twilo. “I wanted to use pods like they did in Invasion of the Body Snatchers,” Reiner added. “When I couldn’t, I decided to use walnuts. When Rob’s wife Laura [played by  ] comes sliding out of the hall closet on two thousand walnuts, that was worth the price of admission. We later gave those walnuts to charity.” The Dick Van Dyke show won 15 Emmys – three for its star and five for Reiner, who described Van Dyke as “maybe the most talented man I’d ever seen”. Audiences simply fell in love with Van Dyke’s character, the head writer on the fictional Alan Brady Show. Reiner played the egocentric, toupee-wearing Brady. “I had the most fun,” said Van Dyke, describing his time on the show as “the best five years of my life”. Part of this was down to his wonderful comic chemistry with Tyler Moore, and part was because of the quality of the dialogue by Reiner and his team of scriptwriters. When Van Dyke’s first wife Margie visited the set of the sitcom, she told him it didn’t look like he was acting at all. “You’re exactly like you are at home,” she said. Loose-limbed Van Dyke’s gift for slapstick stunts remains impressive. “Here’s a guy who is a physical comedian. ‘How do you make room for that and make it feel justified?’ we asked Dick,” revealed Shakman. “We learned so much from it. He told us about the general rule of thumb, which is, ‘if it can happen in real life, it can happen on the show,’ and I believe in that. Drawing on that experience makes room for as many falls over ottomans as you want.” Shakman was referring to the opening credits, in which Van Dyke falls over an ottoman footstool as he enters his living room, one of the most famous tumbles in television history. Van Dyke, who was born in West Plains, Missouri, on 13 December 1925, was “a Laurel and Hardy nut” when he was growing up, idolising the physical comedy of Laurel. During the making of The Dick Van Dyke Show, he came across Laurel’s listing in the local Californian telephone book and gave him a call out of the blue. He told the English-born comedian that he had imitated his pratfalls from an early age and “stolen from you pretty liberally”. “Yes, I know,” replied Laurel cheerily. The two men became friends, and Van Dyke later delivered a eulogy at Laurel’s funeral. There was plenty of bittersweet comedy in Van Dyke’s own family history. His father Loren was a former minor-league baseball player who ended up eking out a living as a travelling salesman for the Sunshine Cookie Company. He was then always known to friends and family as ‘Cookie’. It seems that Cookie crumbled after he fathered Van Dyke out of wedlock, with a stenographer called Hazel McCord. “Suddenly, the good life, as he knew it, vanished and he got a job as a salesman,” Van Dyke recalled in 2016 of his upbringing in Danville, Illinois. “He hated the work, but always had a shine on his shoes and a smile on his face. Years later, when I saw Death of a Salesman, I was depressed for a month. It was Dad’s story.” Although Van Dyke and his brother Jerry sometimes saw flashes of the witty bon vivant that their relatives remembered from better days, they always recognised the sad, quiet clown beneath the mask. Van Dyke remembered his mother as being far more talkative. “If she had a deficiency, it was absent-mindedness. She once cooked a ham and later found it in my father’s shirt drawer,” he added. Van Dyke, who was certified with a “highly gifted” IQ of 150, began to think of a career in showbusiness after making his mark as a radio announcer – first in high school and later after enlisting with the US Air Force – and was keenly aware of the power of publicity. He was “too broke” to marry his high-school sweetheart Margie Willett, but when a radio station agreed to pay for a honeymoon if they wed live on air, he readily agreed. “So, in 1948, we exchanged our vows in front of a minister and two radio microphones while 15 million people listened,” he explained. After working as a radio DJ, he pursued a career on Broadway. Television producer Sheldon Leonard spotted his potential after seeing him in a production of Bye Bye Birdie, suggesting to Reiner that he cast him in the television show that made him famous. His success brought Hollywood offers. After reprising his stage role of Albert Peterson in a film version of Bye Bye Birdie, he was offered the role of Bert (and the ageing Mr Dawes) in Mary Poppins, one of the most popular musicals of all time. Van Dyke starred opposite the eponymous nanny Julie Andrews. He said he was completely unaware during the shoot that anything was wrong with his Cockney accent, taught to him by a dialogue coach from Ireland. “I was working with an entire English cast and nobody said a word, not Julie Andrews, not anybody said I needed to work on it, so I thought I was alright,” he lamented in 2014. Even so, he was convinced that “something magical was going on,” in Mary Poppins, especially with the songs. Van Dyke grew up steeped in music – his father had played saxophone in a jazz band – and was a keen pianist. He went on to record several of his own albums, including one with the Ray Charles Singers. Van Dyke said he understood why cinema-goers connected with the lyrics, especially the “ridiculous word” supercalifragilisticexpialidocious. He said the catchy tunes Chim Chim Cher-ee, Let’s Go Fly a Kite, A Spoonful of Sugar and Feed the Birds, “didn’t just get under my skin, they became part of me then and never left”. Van Dyke had a well-earned reputation in Hollywood as a perfectionist. During the 1967 film Divorce American Style, he spent three days choreographing a single sequence, in order to perfect the timing of a scene in which he and his screen wife Debbie Reynolds open and slam closet doors, cabinet doors and bathroom doors after a bitter row. The following year, he starred in Chitty Chitty Bang Bang. In his 2011 autobiography My Lucky Life in and Out of Show Business, he reveals that it was a role he “repeatedly turned down”. The casting was random. “Dick Van Dyke was older than me and I was playing his dad,” Lionel Jeffries, who starred as Grandpa Potts, remarked. After a big-money offer secured his participation, Van Dyke quickly regretted his involvement. He fell out with director Ken Hughes, who admitted he was “unenthusiastic” about a film based on Ian Fleming’s children’s book, using  s screenplay. Van Dyke overheard Hughes make a disparaging remark about the size of his nose (“what are we going to do about his hooter?”) and he later upbraided Hughes about his habit of swearing in front of the child actors. “Quite simply, I thought he was wrong for the picture,” wrote Van Dyke. “One day I heard him grouse that he had to rewrite Roald Dahl’s script. Who rewrote Roald Dahl?” Despite all the problems, Van Dyke excelled as Caractacus Pott, the eccentric inventor who creates a magical car. The musical numbers were memorable, including the title song, Hushabye Mountain and Truly Scrumptious. Van Dyke, who had always been a keen dancer, had his work cut out on the ensemble version of Me Ol’ Bamboo, a Morris dancing-based tune devised around composer Richard Sherman’s memories of England, when he used a bamboo walking stick. Van Dyke lost 15 pounds rehearsing that gruelling song over and over. “The bamboo sticks had metal poles inside and we had to jump over them and dance with them,” Van Dyke, who was 41 at the time, said in a TV documentary about the making of the film. “Most of the dancers were 15 years younger than me and it took us 23 takes to get it right. In the last take, I only just make it. This was the hardest dance number I ever did.” Van Dyke remained cheerfully candid about the film’s idiosyncrasies, including the fact that the English rain meant that many of the scenes were filmed in France. “We ran out of sunshine so filmed in the south of France, it’s all vineyards, you can see lots of grapes,” he said with a laugh. He didn’t enjoy driving the famous car, either, which he described as “very hard to handle and almost impossible to turn”. Although film offers continued to pour in, it became increasingly clear to Van Dyke that he had a serious drinking problem, something he had “deluded” himself into thinking he could handle, even after recognising that the drunken scenes he played in Divorce American Style were uncomfortably close to home. He likened his alcoholism to heroin addiction. “I tried to be a good role model to my children, but I was an alcoholic for 25 years, which inevitably impacted on family life,” he said. Margie, who suffered a miscarriage of twins before they had four children, was also struggling with her own problems. “When I pledged to quit and entered a rehab clinic, Margie checked in as I checked out. I thought she’d come to pick me up, but it turned out she was hooked on anti-depressants. I had no idea. What a pair,” he admitted in 2016. Van Dyke acknowledged that his drinking brought “personality changes” and mood swings. “I was in deep trouble, you get suicidal and think you just can’t go on. I had suicidal feelings, it was just terrible. But then suddenly, like a blessing, the drink started not to taste good,” he told The Telegraph that same year. By then, the actor was with his third wife, makeup artist Arlene Silver. After divorcing Margie in 1984, he spent the next 35 years with former actress Michelle Triola (Lee Marvin’s former girlfriend and a plaintiff against him in a famous palimony suit) who died in 2009 from lung cancer. He married Arlene in 2012, and both have talked in gushing terms about their happiness. Van Dyke dubbed their relationship “a second childhood”, while Silver, who is 46 years younger than her husband, called it “a fairytale”. When asked in 2014 what kept him youthful, Van Dyke quipped: “My young wife… she puts me in the fridge.” It is striking just how enthusiastic and joyful Van Dyke has remained, despite the ups and downs of life. In one reflective moment, in a 2011 interview with USA Today, he talked about his sanguine world view. “The only philosophy I have is that there is no such thing as security – not financial, not emotional, not anything. Insecurity is what exists and I think people make the mistake of trying to build security for themselves. If you can just live with that wisdom, of knowing there isn’t any security, that is a way of relaxing and sitting loosely in the saddle of life that’s much better, because you don’t worry,” he said. Although he was honest enough to admit he “gladly said ‘Yes’ to a hodgepodge of TV movies”, Van Dyke will be remembered for a rich legacy of work beyond his hit show and the two movie triumphs. Although certain projects never came to fruition – he wanted to play Stan Laurel in a biopic and King Lear on stage, and made the “stupid” decision to turn down the lead role in The Omen – he earned a Golden Globe nomination for The New Dick Van Dyke Show, a series written and directed by Reiner that ran from 1971 to 1974, about a Phoenix television talk show host. He went on to win a Golden Globe for ‘Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series’ for a 1989 episode of The Golden Girls. His successful role as a doctor in Diagnosis Murder, which aired from 1993 to 2001, also enabled him to wrangle work for his family. His brother Jerry – who joked that “I’ve been hanging on his coat-tails for 80 years” – son Barry and grandson Shane all appeared in that long-running medical crime drama, prompting Van Dyke to quip that “I took nepotism to its final point.” In his final senior citizen career days, Van Dyke moved into more villainous territory, playing a corrupt policeman in Warren Beatty’s Dick Tracy and a scheming security guard in Ben Stiller’s Night at the Museum. Nonagenarian, Van Dyke continued to keep fit – working out at the gym most days and swimming regularly – and penning, at 90, the book Keep Moving: And Other Tips and Truths About Aging. The actor railed against the way that “ageism has become the last acceptable form of discrimination.” In one poignant interview he reflected on the fact that he had lived so long that “my whole generation has disappeared on me,” reflecting on lost friends such as Paul Newman, Jack Lemmon and his Malibu neighbour and friend Charles Bronson, who always gave Van Dyke a lemon cake for Christmas. Van Dyke took heart in the way he remained revered as a pioneer by modern comedians. When Van Dyke conducted a Q&A at the 2017 Salt Lake Comic Con, Rob Schneider spoke to him from the audience, saying: “You planted the seeds and we have all been stealing from you for 55 years or so.” Schneider, a star of Saturday Night Live, also brought up the old chestnut joke by asking whether it was true that Dick Van Dyke had changed his name from Penis Van Lesbian? “I’ve had to live with that joke for so many years,” replied the 91-year-old amiably. He also showed his lighter side after being awarded the Britannia Award for Excellence in Television at the 2017 BAFTA awards. “They asked whom I would like to present the award, so I sent them a list of a whole load of dead people, including Laurence Olivier,” he joked. Van Dyke, humble and broad-minded, is a man of surprises. His hobbies include creating his own computer animations and singing in a Barbershop Quartet (his group, the Vantastix, once sang ‘The Star-Spangled Banner’ before an LA Lakers basketball game). He is active on Instagram and Twitter and made public his dislike of Donald Trump (“there’s something missing”). He’s also a man with a social conscience, even in his 90s volunteering at the Los Angeles homeless charity The Midnight Mission. “I go down Thanksgiving, Christmas and Easter, and I dance, I sing, I greet people at the door,” he said. Happily, his dancing feet still work, something evident in his cameo role in 2018’s Mary Poppins Returns, in which he played Mr. Dawes Jr. Production designer John Myre said he was concerned because the elderly actor’s dance scene “called for a big leap on to the desk of Colin Firth’s character, followed by a tap-dance break”. Dick Van Dyke told Myre to remove the safety steps that had been constructed. Myre said he executed his moves “flawlessly”. Dick Van Dyke fans had been hoping that there was one last television hurrah, with a guest appearance on the finale of WandaVision. Shakman was coy in January when asked about a possible cameo (“I couldn't possibly say,” he remarked), but speculation intensified when Bettany remarked that “there’s a huge reveal with an actor that I’ve always wanted to work with, and I have some real explosive scenes with him.” Van Dyke sadly didn't appear in the WandaVision finale. But that won't dampen the spirits of one of entertainment’s most upbeat performers. “I’ve had such a life and so much fun,” Van Dyke said recently. “I don’t regret a minute of it. I’ve just had the best time you can imagine.”

heading: The Wonder Woman that wasn’t: inside George Miller’s unmade Justice League movie
subheading: Armie Hammer as Batman; an evil Superman; a $250m budget. Why was the pre-Zack Snyder Justice League: Mortal scrapped?
author: Anthony Brett
article: In an alternate dimension, Armie Hammer’s role in Call Me by Your Name would have been a risky departure for an actor best known for playing Batman. Mad Max: Fury Road may never have happened. And Megan Gale would have been a name on everybody’s lips. These were elements of Justice League: Mortal, an early incarnation of the Justice League movie that spectacularly flamed out in 2017 after being botched by Joss Whedon, and has now  . But before both version, Justice League: Mortal was due for a 2009 release under the directorial eye of Mad Max: Fury Road mastermind George Miller. Hollywood projects falling apart over time are nothing new, but Miller’s Justice League very nearly happened. By the time the film had been axed by Warner Bros over issues with its budget, its stars and its script, an array of actors had been cast, costumes had been designed and production was about to begin. It remains one of Hollywood’s most infamous unmade films. Information about the proposed movie has been leaked in anecdotes and concept art here and there over the years, forming a remarkable picture of a slightly muddled - if undeniably intriguing - comic book movie that never came to be. The film’s script, leaked online in 2013 and credited to married writing duo Michele and Kieran Mulroney, depicted Batman as an untrustworthy and vaguely dictatorial crime fighter who creates a surveillance machine known as the Brother Eye, which would monitor the Justice League of America and fellow super-powered civilians. This, surprise-surprise, would fall into the villainous hands of businessman Maxwell Lord, who would hijack the machine and create killer robots to battle the team. Justice League: Mortal somewhat oddly positioned The Flash as its central character, who would later sacrifice his life to save the day in the film’s final face-off. In addition, as Maxwell Lord actor Jay Baruchel told the Happy Sad Confused podcast, Superman would turn evil over the course of the film and battle Wonder Woman. “I turn him into full red-eye Superman,” Baruchel recalled. “And then there’s this big-ass fight between him and Wonder Woman, where he breaks her f------ wrists and s---, and then I die halfway through the movie, and then my consciousness is uploaded into a f------ mainframe and I’m an evil computer.” Production art, prosthetic tests and storyboards have leaked over the years, one by artist Steve Skroce depicting the aforementioned Superman/Wonder Woman fight (though he has since deleted the images), and others depicting Aquaman in costume and Wonder Woman’s home of Themyscira. A  has been in the works for years, and will hopefully see light of day when filmmaker Ryan Unicomb manages to get permission to use characters and images from Warner Bros. This incarnation of Justice League was developed at a particularly hopeful time for DC Comics and Warner Bros, who had achieved success with Batman Begins, the first entry in Christopher Nolan’s acclaimed Batman trilogy, and were about to launch a fresh take on the Superman mythos courtesy of Bryan Singer. In September 2007, inspired by the Mulroney script, Miller had signed on to direct the superhero team-up movie, and quickly began to assemble his cast. Looking back at the various breathless casting reports at the time is like taking a glance at the young Hollywood of 2007 in microcosm. There was Adam Brody, fresh from his role in The OC. Jessica Biel and Mary Elizabeth Winstead were both linked to Wonder Woman; the cast of Friday Night Lights read for numerous roles; and rapper Common auditioned at a time when he was eager to break into acting. One-time big-deals including Shannyn Sossamon, Michael Angarano and Joseph Cross were also accounted for during auditions. According to the Hollywood Reporter, Miller was specifically looking for young actors who would be able to “grow into their roles over the course of several movies.” They were also noticeably less expensive than the ensembles of Batman Begins and Superman Returns. Ultimately cast were Armie Hammer (long before his  ) as Batman, TV actor DJ Cotrona as Superman, Australian model Megan Gale as Wonder Woman, Common as Green Lantern, Brody as The Flash, the late Anton Yelchin as his nephew Wally West, Heroes actor Santiago Cabrera as Aquaman and the lateGeorge Miller regular Hugh Keays-Byrne as the Martian Manhunter. Other roles cast included The Big Sick’s Zoe Kazan as The Flash’s love interest Iris Allen, Stephen Tobolowsky as Alfred Pennyworth, Teresa Palmer as Talia al Ghul and Judd Apatow regular Jay Baruchel as villain Maxwell Lord. As Hammer told Vulture in 2010, Miller’s pre-production work on the film had been extensive. “They had pre-vizzed a lot of the special-effects sequences, and we saw some of the fight sequences without even having filmed them yet.” He continued: “There was a giant room that he had turned into the storyboard room — this huge conference room that had floor-to-ceiling storyboards on the walls — and you’d start at one point and just walk around the entire room and by the time you were done, it was frame-for-frame the entire movie. We saw it on paper and we were going to bring it to life, we just never got the chance.” The actors had also tried on their costumes, with Hammer describing his Batman costume as having been made from incredibly luxury fabrics. “His utility belt was made from the finest Italian leather and highly polished, and the things that would come out of his forearm, they were titanium but wrapped in very fine leather.” He also revealed that his Batman would have been the first to be able to turn his head in his cowl. An impending writer’s strike had rushed the film into production based on just a few drafts of a script, but as work began, Warner Bros reportedly got cold feet. There had long been concerns about a Justice League movie potentially confusing the marketplace, particularly as the trilogy was in full swing. That had been publicly exacerbated months earlier, when Batman star Christian Bale told reporters that he had not been contacted to play the Caped Crusader in the film, and declared that “It’d be better if [Justice League] doesn’t tread on the toes of what our Batman series is doing.” According to the New York Times, the Mulroneys journeyed to Australia in March 2008 to work on the script with Miller, amid concerns that “the screenplay did not quite meet the challenge of introducing a new series without undercutting the old ones.” The delay in production also meant options on the cast lapsed, allowing them to sign up to other work. This wasn’t a pressing concern, however, as they had reportedly bonded with Miller during trips to his Australian home and were all eager to film the movie. But another problem was on the horizon: namely that the film could no longer be shot in Australia. Miller, who has rarely directed films outside of his native country, was counting on a 40 per cent tax rebate from the Australian government, who would help finance the film in exchange for the work the project would bring to the country. At a reported cost of $250 million, Justice League would have been largely unthinkable without state help. Australia’s federal government eventually declared Justice League would not receive the 40% rebate, citing a perceived lack of Australian actors in the main cast (that was despite Gale, Palmer and Keays-Byrne all hailing from Down Under). As a result, Warner Bros suspended production. An outraged Miller told the Sydney Morning Herald: “A once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for the Australian film industry is being frittered away because of very lazy thinking. If that’s going to be the final decision, they’re throwing away hundreds of millions of dollars of investment that the rest of the world is competing for and, much more significantly, highly skilled creative jobs.” In light of the decision, production was moved to Canada, with Warner Bros aiming to start shooting in July 2008 for a summer 2009 release. But July came and went, and on the heels of the enormous critical and commercial success of Christopher Nolan’s The Dark Knight, released that month, Warner Bros and DC decided to regroup. “We’re not off the notion of a Justice League,” president of WB production Jeff Robinov told Variety at the time. “There’s a massive interest and knowledge in the comic book industry and it takes time to sort of catch up and understand the characters and the history, where they’ve intersected with each other and what their worlds are. That’s part of the education that we’re going through.” The senior VP of creative affairs for DC Comics, Gregory Noveck, added: “These are big, iconic characters. So when you make them into a movie, you’d better be shooting for a pretty high standard. You’re not always going to reach it, but you have to be shooting for it. We’re going to make a Justice League movie, whether it’s now or 10 years from now. But we’re not going to do it and Warners is not going to do it until we know it’s right.” By the end of 2008, Justice League was as good as dead, and Miller announced on Australian television that he had left the project. Declaring that he was no longer involved “in any capacity”, he also implied that the low-wattage of the cast was also a factor, claiming that the studio “seems to want bigger stars in their superhero movies now.” In the years that have passed, several cast members have spoken about the project, with a mix of both sadness over what they felt was a missed opportunity, as well as a slight shrug over its eventual demise. “For a long time, I was like, ‘How great that could have been!’” Hammer told Vulture. “[But] as a 31-year-old who’s been through a lot since I was 19, I wouldn’t want to watch a 19-year-old Batman. I’d be like, ‘Who’s this spoiled rich kid who wants to play dress-up?’” “I used to be upset we didn’t get to do it, but everything happens exactly as it’s supposed to,” he continued. “I still have a lot of learning to do about this, and it’s a constant pursuit for me. If I had been that successful right out of the gate, I would have thought I already understood it all. I know that I wouldn’t have turned in a great performance, or even a good performance — it would have just been whatever. So I’m glad.” “It was a great script, and it was a great director,” Adam Brody told HeyUGuys in 2013. “I’m not saying it would have changed the world, but that movie would have worked, I will say that. [It] would have been a nice little movie I think, but they [Warner Brothers] just didn’t want to cross their streams with a whole bunch of Batmans in the universe and all the other reasons they didn’t make it. “I will say that I don’t have any particular affinity for the Flash. I grew up reading comic books, and loving them, and I still have a fondness for them. Although the older I get, the more saturated the marketplace gets, I find the less I care as a whole.” Even Miller has been slightly “meh” on its lack of existence. “It was very faithful to the comics at the time, very DCU,” he told the Word Balloon podcast. “Ultimately I think it’s good that it didn’t come out as there were some parts that were cool that they got right and there were some things that people were going to hate. Some of it was very aimed at kids.” Speaking to Australia’s Channel Nine, Gale had a slightly warmer response: “As long as my son thinks I’m Wonder Woman [I'm fine],” Gale told “If that means I’m ‘super-mum’, I’m fine.” Along with crediting the film for her friendship with Miller, who would later cast her in Mad Max: Fury Road, she also spoke proudly of a photograph she took in costume that was leaked online in 2015. “It was a really lovely surprise, because I hadn’t seen it for seven years. We were just doing costume trials. We just did full dress, costume and hair and wardrobe, and we did a photo shoot. But I’m glad that we got that far into production that we had those photos!” Miller’s departure from Justice League was met with odd celebration by fans, who had taken to slamming the director as “just the guy who did Happy Feet” and mocking his casting choices. The fresh-faced, all-American Hammer, then a complete unknown, had been repeatedly dubbed “Frat-Man”. “Since he was announced as the director of Justice League, I’ve grown to dislike him and his idiotic casting choices,” wrote Alex Billington of First Showing in 2008. “I couldn’t be happier that he’s no longer involved!” In hindsight, such a reaction is slightly embarrassing. On paper, Justice League: Mortal had story issues, while the timing of its intended release and its lack of relationship with the Nolan trilogy indicated a lack of thinking on the part of Warner Bros bosses… something that has been replicated ever since. But Miller would also go on to direct one of the 21st century’s most relentlessly exciting and justifiably heralded blockbusters in the form of Mad Max: Fury Road, and it remains intriguing to imagine what he would have done with the superhero genre. In light of Zack Snyder’s nonsensically grim adaptations and the Joss Whedon snark crudely stuck onto it with scotch tape, it really couldn’t have been much worse. “It was allegorical, like a story of Greek Gods almost,” Cotrona told Slashfilm in 2015. “He was doing things with the Superman character and Batman character, and all the iconic favourites, that’s never been done before. Watch Fury Road and you can only imagine what he would do with those iconic characters.”

heading: What’s on TV tonight: The Syndicate, Being Jewish and more
subheading: Your complete guide to the week’s television, films and sport, across terrestrial and digital platforms
author: Telegraph Reporters
article: It’s been six years since Kay Mellor’s soapy drama about lottery winners was last on the box – inexplicably, since it’s an amiable ensemble piece that makes a change from detective dramas. The fourth series has the same basic premise as before – five Yorkshire-based folk, this time kennel employees about to be made gig workers, pick the winning numbers. Mellor sets the scene prior to their win: the twentysomethings are all in financial and emotional straits that will provide grist to the drama mill; one character is secretly pregnant, another fearful of a relative’s imminent release from prison. Episode one focuses on Keeley (Katherine Rose Morley), whose gambling addiction has resulted in debt collectors banging on the door. Neil Morrissey and Gaynor Faye play the newsagents who redeem the ticket – middle-aged sweethearts whose imminent wedding plans are derailed. The familiar Mellor ingredients are there – ordinary northerners with empty pockets and big hearts wrestling with crushed dreams. We’re rooting for them, especially when it transpires that there’s a problem for the youngsters in collecting their winnings, a twist that provides narrative drive and levity. A winner.  The return of Fred Sirieix’s culinary TV tour sees him escorted by Nadiya Hussain around her favourite Yorkshire eateries. Sampling fondant fancies at Bettys Tea Café Rooms is a jammy gig for the pair, and their gentle bickering over the etiquette of dunking makes it work as entertainment. The brilliance of this series lies in its bleak, believable rendering of real-life detective work. It raises our admiration immeasurably for the Manchester police wading through CCTV footage and chivvying along witnesses in a bid to crack a shocking case. It turns out that American Joe Exotic (aka the Tiger King) isn’t the only one keeping dangerous wild animals in his backyard. In this two-part documentary, Ross Kemp explores how easy it is in Britain to keep wild cats at home. Visiting, among others, show jumper Reece Oliver and his two pet lions in Nottinghamshire, Kemp’s incredulity and distaste are evident. Hard on the heels of the previous series, adventurer Ben Fogle embarks on another round of home visits to off-gridders. Setting down his rucksack in Ullapool in the Highlands, he mucks in with Iona and Julien, who drive cattle and produce their own hydroelectricity. The shameful rise in anti-Semitism is just one reason why this sympathetic series feels apposite. Several British Jews explain the importance of their faith as we follow them to milestone ceremonies, including the bar mitzvah of Ethan, who movingly uses the occasion to memorialise a Holocaust victim who didn’t live to have his. It’s followed by Being Hindu, in which cameras follow a Tamil wedding. Irish playwright Colm Tóibín’s 2019 one-woman play, performed with coiled energy by Lisa Dwan, is the flip side of Sophocles’s Antigone. We hear her story through the words of her sister, Ismene, who explores her own guilt at being a survivor.   ★★★☆☆ A breezy and enjoyable comedy from Peter Hedges (About a Boy). Steve Carell plays Dan, a schlumpy, lovable newspaper columnist who writes about parenting but proves inept at bringing up his children on his own. Then he falls for Marie (Juliette Binoche), only to discover that she’s dating his brother. It’s undoubtedly predictable and saccharine, but Hedges directs with a sure hand and Carell is a charmingly crumpled everyman.   ★★★☆☆ This low-key and rather dark comedy, starring Alec Guinness, was written and co-produced by JB Priestley and directed by Henry Cass. Informed that he has a short time to live, underachieving salesman George (Guinness) finds that his resolution to live his remaining life to the full and take risks brings him more advantages than just a good time. The irony is laid on thick, but Guinness is masterful as a man filled with a sudden thirst for life.  ★★★☆☆    Rooney Mara plays the titular unsung apostle with alabaster poise who opts for a life on the road with Jesus Christ (Joaquin Phoenix) in this austere biblical drama from Lion director Garth Davis. It’s solemn, strange and oh-so-tastefully done with Etsy-friendly shawls and rugged coastlines, but its thought-provoking rather than overwhelmingly powerful. Still, Phoenix plays Jesus with a guru-like intensity, and the ensemble cast are superb.  Those who feel a little Gyles Brandreth goes a long way may want to steer clear of Channel 5 for the next few Wednesdays, as he explores the lives and works of Thomas Hardy, Charles Dickens and the Brontë sisters. That said, he’s on relatively restrained form for this opening episode, reining in the archness and not dressing up any more than, say, Lucy Worsley might on a similar assignment to visit key locations in Jane Austen’s life and talk to the experts. Along the way he encounters the scribblings of a teenage Jane that showcase her imagination already at work, splicing her name with a fictional person called Fitzwilliam. He takes the waters in Bath just as she did while accompanying her brother in search of a cure for his gout, and joins the Austentatious improv gang for a skit, alongside more serious excursions into her political views and private life. None of it will come as news to hardened Janeites (a term popularised by confirmed fan Rudyard Kipling), but that’s hardly the point. Bursting with clips from the many Austen adaptations of recent years, this is literature done Channel 5 style, and none the worse for that.  It doesn’t seem so long ago that Fifa made the bizarre and contentious decision to award the 2022 World Cup to Qatar – a desert nation with little footballing history, but lots of oil money. England’s qualification campaign will likely come down to two matches against a talented Poland side, with the first at Wembley this Wednesday. First, on Sunday, England travel to Tirana to face Albania in what should be a more straightforward affair (ITV, 4.10pm). Meanwhile, Wales host Czech Republic in Cardiff on Tuesday and, on Wednesday, Scotland play Faroe Islands at Hampden Park (both Sky Main Event, 7.45pm) and Northern Ireland take on Bulgaria in Belfast. Also on Wednesday, Chelsea play Wolfsburg (BT Sport, 1pm) and Manchester City take on Barcelona (4pm) in the Women’s Champions League quarter-final second legs. City have it all to do after losing the first leg 3-0; Chelsea are 2-1 up.  This thorough two-parter focuses on how gardens reflect personalities and the ways in which the magpie instincts of famous horticulturalists and designers have been turned towards creating a particularly English take on the garden. The series begins with the era from the Romans to the Renaissance, and the history is brought up to date tomorrow evening. Rob Rinder joins the regulars in this strange but compelling series trying to pick the real homeowner (in this case, “Michael”) apart from the impostors. What conclusions can they draw when one Michael can’t remember anything about their life, or when another essays an oddly familiar chat-up line? Mutinous mutterings swell in volume as further men die on the long trek to safety, while no less a public figure than Charles Dickens (Tristan Teller) is enlisted to help in raising finance back in London for a rescue expedition as the irresistibly bleak and evocative thriller approaches its conclusion. Always “Matthew” to his mother, Janice, TV presenter Matt Baker, and his family, rushed from Hertfordshire to the family farm in the Durham Dales when Janice was trampled by a herd of sheep. With Janice recuperating and her husband Mike unable to run the farm alone, the Bakers are forced to make big decisions about the future. It’s all captured by this engagingly intimate series which, while light and entertaining for the most part, has serious things to say about ageing and filial relations. Part of the BBC’s ongoing festival of theatre recast for television and radio, David Ireland’s play unflinchingly examines the life of one Belfast cleaner (Abigail McGibbon), who confronts ghosts of her past raised by her new and intense relationship with a younger man. The last instalment of this fine documentary series finds doubts afflicting some of the hopeful parents, while others find navigating the unique relationship between intended and surrogate parents particularly testing as the due dates approach. A tough, but heartening watch.   ★★★★★ From its F-bomb-laced opening to its tear-jerking use of WH Auden’s Funeral Blues, Richard Curtis’s romcom is a stone-cold British classic. (It’s still the highest grossing British release of all time.) It made a star of Hugh Grant – he was the 72nd actor to audition for the role – as the lovelorn, floppy-haired rogue Charles who falls in love with an American (Andie MacDowell) at his best friend’s wedding. Glorious.  ★★★☆☆ Ambitious young director Craig Roberts (he made his first film aged only 24) bites off a little more than he can chew in this indie-inflected take on paranoid schizophrenia. Sally Hawkins is Jane, a woman whose grasp on reality is cracked by meds, her horrid family and imaginary terrors. But despite the talented cast, Roberts can’t decide whether he’s making a comedy or a serious drama about mental illness. In the end, it’s neither.  ★★★★★ Ang Lee’s pitch-perfect adaptation of the Jane Austen novel brought Kate Winslet fame and Emma Thompson a deserved Oscar. They play sisters Marianne and Elinor, both in want of a husband but attracted to rather different ways of getting one. The famous scene in which shy Elinor (Thompson) receives the proposal she has longed for is a masterclass in restraint. Also starring Alan Rickman and Hugh Grant. It’s not just Harry and Meghan who are embracing the media these days. Lady Pamela Hicks, daughter of Lord Mountbatten, cousin of the Duke of Edinburgh, bridesmaid, companion and lifelong friend of the Queen, has been in revelatory mode recently, too, in a podcast made by her daughter, India. Never known to let a royal-related tell-all escape its grip, ITV has picked up this one-off filmed at home in Oxfordshire, in which Lady Pamela, now 91, and India, 53, look back over an exceptionally glamorous life lived right at the top of the tree. But those looking for scandal will have to look elsewhere. Unlike Harry and Meghan, there’s no word of criticism of the royals or any little idiosyncrasies they might have. Quite the opposite. “She’s an amazing person,” Lady Pamela says of the Queen. “There’s such inner strength there and she’s remained like that throughout her life.” Inevitably odd scraps leak out, relating to the Princess Royal’s hand-me-downs or the Queen’s celebrated thrift, but otherwise this is an unadulterated love letter to the Queen from one of her closest friends. While the Palace might prefer this approach, you do miss Oprah’s pizzazz.  We all have stories connected to particular pieces of clothing, items that instantly summon up the past. This new eight-parter based on a bestselling book by Emily Spivack opens a multitude of wardrobe doors and bottom drawers to see how deeply clothes are bound up with identity, creativity and memory. The show featuring business start-ups pitching for investment from a panel of entrepreneurial titans gets its 18th series off to a feelgood start with an unusually high number of successes. Not least the (traditionally triumphant) closing pitch, in which a couple with strong links to the NHS negotiate one of the most successful “equity climbdowns” in Dragons’ Den history.   Another round of heart-melting canine adoption stories as more rescue dogs are matched with their new forever families, including a pug inclined to fainting fits, a lurcher meant to mend a broken heart, and a lively Jack Russell with enough energy to follow his adventurous new owners anywhere – even on wheels. Should you not be content with your own, or even the UK’s, experience of Covid-19, this absorbing new documentary series tells the story of the pandemic from a global perspective through the experiences – and very widely varying attitudes – of people from all around the world, beginning in Wuhan. Events of the recent past make for grim but compelling viewing. If lockdown’s left you missing your April Fools japes, there’s plenty of pranking in tonight’s helping of comical challenges. Among the highlights are Lee Mack attempting a hammer throw and Sarah Kendall endeavouring to make sitting down more memorable. Greg Davies and Alex Horne present. Two decades since their hit sitcom Home Improvement came to an end, Tim Allen (known to millions as the voice of Buzz Lightyear) and Richard Karn are reunited for this small scale but entertaining challenge in which competitors test their DIY skills by trying to build or repair anything demanded of them by the hosts, from a do-it-yourself jacuzzi to a barbecue that doubles as a bicycle. It’s larky, Boy’s Own fun.  ★★★☆☆ Kevin Macdonald’s film (nominated for five Baftas) is a legal thriller of sorts, but one with a timeline that sets about defeating suspense: a 14-year incarceration without trial. It’s based on Mohamedou Ould Salahi’s 2015 memoir Guantánamo Diary, but retold without much friction. What lifts it to a major degree is Tahar Rahim’s performance as Salahi and Jodie Foster as his formidable defence attorney Nancy Hollander (a recent Golden Globe win). ★★★★★ Carol Reed confirmed his position as one of Britain’s greatest directors with this film noir, which oozes atmosphere and crackles with suspense. American writer Holly Martin (Joseph Cotten) is offered a new job in Vienna by his friend Harry (Orson Welles). But upon his arrival, Holly is told that Harry is dead. Refusing to accept this, he begins his own investigation. Graham Greene adapted his own novella for the screenplay. ★★★★★ This darkly brilliant farce by satirist Chris Morris, which finds the funny side of terrorism, was met with controversy on its release, and shows no signs of losing its bite. It charts the journey of five hapless British would-be jihadists, including family man Omar (Riz Ahmed), as they plan a mass suicide attack. What ensues is a comedy of errors, as they all are distracted on their road to paradise. Rubber dinghy rapids, anyone?  For many of us, what we look forward to most once the pandemic is over is the opportunity to travel again. Following on from its wanderlust-inducing series on great railway journeys, Channel 5 provides inspiration aplenty in this new six-part series, narrated by perennial favourite Bill Nighy, giving us a taste of some of the finest inland waterways on the planet. Among the rivers are the Danube, Mississippi and our very own River Spey in Scotland. But we begin with a trip down one of North America’s mightiest waterways, the Niagara River which runs along the border between Ontario in Canada and New York state in the US, before plunging headlong into the gorge beneath the world-famous Niagara Falls. Connecting two of the Great Lakes (Ontario and Erie), it is a short but tremendously powerful river, which over the millennia has carved out some stunning riverside landscapes. The journey begins with a short hop on a US Coast Guard launch out of Buffalo, upriver through the Chippawa Channel towards the Falls, then onwards through dizzying gorges, whirlpools and rapids before finishing with a tour of Canada’s breathtaking wine country. You’ll be longing to book plane tickets.  A unique recital of Easter sacred music featuring each of the Tenebrae vocal ensemble’s 20 singers filmed and recorded separately in isolation, under the direction of Nigel Short.
