Amy Fearn was the first woman to referee an EFL game as she came on as an injury replacement in the 2010 Championship game between Coventry and Nottingham Forest. But Welch is the first to be given a game from the off. She added: "My dad is my biggest fan so pre-Covid he came to every single game, he was over the moon, my mum doesn't know a lot about football so she is excited but I don't think she knows why she is excited. "They are really proud so that is really nice."

heading: Dickie Bird exclusive: 'Lockdown has been very difficult but Yorkshire put years on my life'
subheading: Umpiring legend has endured a lonely year of shielding at home yet fresh air, exercise and his cricketing family have kept him going
author: Simon Briggs,
article: Dickie Bird’s telephone has rung off the hook over the past fortnight, carrying good wishes from afar. “I had calls from Australia and South Africa,” he says. “Richard Hadlee rang me from New Zealand. I had messages from Alastair Cook – that were nice. I were thinking, ‘How did it get all around the world?’” Bird is talking about the short TV interview he recorded a couple of weeks ago. Speaking to BBC  ’s Ian White in his back garden, his voice cracked with emotion as he described the year he has spent on his own, shielding against Covid. “I’ll tell you now, mate, it’s been really hard.” But the abiding impression was of how well he looked. Here he was, 87 years old, the survivor of a serious stroke in 2010. And yet he impressed White with his exercises, scuttling up and down his lawn with unexpectedly quicksilver feet. When  sent a photographer around last week, he was keen to reprise the performance. “You’ll get some good photos,” he promised. “I have a massive garden with a great view of the Pennines, because there’s a lot of beauty in Yorkshire.” Classic Dickie. As an umpire, he often wore a worried frown, especially when dark clouds massed overhead.  : Norman Wisdom meets Bilbo Baggins. As his biographer David Hopps puts it, “There is no side to Dickie, no threat, no hidden agenda.” He will chat to anyone, whether it be an autograph-hunter carrying one of his half-a-dozen books – which have sold over a million copies between them – or the Queen herself. He calculates that he has met Her Majesty 29 times. What Bird hasn’t been able to do for the last 12 months is welcome any visitors to his home in Barnsley. His niece would normally drop around to clean the place once a week, but that has been a non-starter since the first lockdown. His neighbours pick up the supermarket shopping for him, and leave it on his doorstep, whereupon he makes a valiant – if maladroit – attempt to construct a meal. “I’ve burned so many pans,” he said. “I’ve broken so much crockery. I do find that very difficult. I were the same weight – 11st 6lb – for my whole life, but now I’ve lost a couple of pounds. For a treat, I still go to the Wetherby Whaler takeaway on a Friday night for scampi and onion rings. They say, ‘Stay in the car, Dickie.’” (He drives a Jaguar, courtesy of all those book sales.) “‘We’ll bring it over to you.’” A perennial bachelor, Dickie is coming to regret the size of his four-bedroom cottage. “I try and tidy up myself, I try and hoover, but it’s too big. I could do with a bungalow but I’ve got so much stuff it’s unbelievable, even after I’ve given a lot of my memorabilia away. It’s a bit late to move now, though. When they take me out of this house, they’ll take me out in a coffin.” The term “not-outer” once applied to Dickie’s umpiring, but since Covid-19 confined him to barracks, it could be extended to his lifestyle as well. He has been forced to abandon his usual trips to Headingley for lunch, and to Scarborough for Christmas, where he has many old friends. Apart from the weekly meal at the Wetherby Whaler, his only escape is a daily 90-minute walk, which often takes him across the nearby municipal golf course. “I’ve got the freedom of the city,” he pointed out proudly, “so I can go wherever I want.” Before he even sets out, he spends an hour exercising at home – usually in the garden but in his large bathroom if it rains. His routine revolves around those short sprints that featured in the BBC video. “I come up with my own recipe, always have done,” he said. “You’ve got to watch out, because if you get this mental problem, then that’s serious. You have to get some fresh air. Elderly people like to sit in the house, and watch TV from dawn till dusk. I think it’s a nightmare, doing that.”   The last time I interviewed Dickie, I travelled up to Barnsley in person, and found myself in a kind of shrine. The living-room walls carried framed photos of Bird in his distinctive white cap, poised over the stumps as Imran Khan or Ian Botham charged in. The desk showed off all sorts of keepsakes: here, the giant red book he received from  ; there a miniature replica of the statue that stands just south of Barnsley town centre, a life-size bronze with its index finger raised. There is a typically Bird-ish story about that statue. When it was first erected, weekend revellers treated it like something from an X-rated adventure playground. “They had to give it a plinth, make it six foot higher,” Dickie said. “It was the only way to stop women from climbing up and hanging their bras and panties on my finger!” All very eccentric, and very British, just like Dickie himself. He is not one of those old-stagers who moves with the times; rather, he seems to carry the 1950s around with him. Reading  is a reassuring throwback to a time when the world made sense, as calming to the soul as picking up an Agatha Christie or an Arthur Ransome. Remarkably, it remains the most successful volume in the history of British sports publishing, even if no one fully understands how the umpire became bigger than the game. When I asked Dickie’s publisher Roddy Bloomfield for an explanation, he referred me to “the extraordinary sight of this small man standing in the middle, pointing his finger in the face of these 6ft 8in fast bowlers and telling them what’s what. For many people, especially casual viewers, that’s more interesting than a batsman hitting a six.” Ah, yes, casual viewers. Dickie’s appeal extends to the most unlikely people. In 1998, the American horror-writing legend Stephen King took a spontaneous diversion from a book-signing tour to visit the cricket at Trent Bridge, and bonded at once with his fellow author. “Dickie gave him a three-hour tour of the pavilion,” Bloomfield recalled. “They got on famously and Dickie went away with a copy of  , even though he’s never read a word about anything outside cricket.” If there is one thing missing from Dickie’s narrative, it is a chapter on romance. His books are a largely female-free zone, apart from a brief mention of an unnamed South African girl in the 1960s, which gives off a distinct “my girlfriend goes to another school” vibe. Looking back, he says he would have loved children of his own – and indeed he has donated many thousands to the cardiac unit at Great Ormond Street Hospital, “for their tiny hearts”. But marriage? That was never a realistic prospect for someone who spent four straight decades on the road. As Hopps points out, “Dickie must be one of the most loved lonely men – certainly solitary men – in the world.” Fortunately, this son of a miner belongs to a different kind of family: Yorkshire County Cricket Club, which he joined all the way back in 1956 after a knee injury had wrecked his hopes of a football career. If there is a great love story in Bird’s life, this is it. He has contributed financially to the cause, spending £125,000 on the Dickie Bird Players’ Balcony at Headingley. But the emotional ties reach far deeper. “Like most people, Dickie has had his down moments over the winter,” said Yorkshire’s director of cricket, Martyn Moxon, one of several club bigwigs who have called him regularly to chat about sport and generally gee him up. “Overall, though, he is remarkably well, given that he is on his own. In fact, judging by that BBC film, he runs better than me.” It’s heartwarming to witness how much progress Bird has made since my last visit to Barnsley eight years ago. He was still struggling then with the after-effects of his stroke, which left him gloomy and often tearful. That spring morning in 2013, he hadn’t even made it out of bed when I dropped by, which was alarmingly out of character for a man who used to arrive four hours early for a Test match or a chinwag with the Queen. At that stage, his oft-stated maxim that “the characters are going out of the game” seemed liable to apply to Dickie himself. Again, Yorkshire rode to the rescue. Their decision to elect him club president in 2014 proved transformative. “It put years on my life,” he told me, “because I hadn’t been well before. I went all over, riding in the team bus in my club sweater and tie. I didn’t miss a match. It gave me a chance to see old friends, catch up with people I used to know before I retired. I came away a new man.” Dickie takes great pride in the fact that Yorkshire won back-to-back county championships during his two-year term. “That’s never been done in history!” he barks, with childlike glee. “And we haven’t won it since, so some of the members have been saying ‘Bring back Dickie Bird!’” Bring back Dickie Bird? After this toughest of modern winters, it feels like he’s back already.

heading: Hege Riise: Timing of Olympics email which left snubbed keeper in tears was 'big mistake'
subheading: Plus: Analysis of England's options in Steph Houghton's absence as Riise announces squad for friendlies against France and Canada
author: Tom Garry,
article: Team GB and England head coach Hege Riise says it was a "big mistake" that several players found out they were not on the Olympics squad shortlist shortly before kick-off in a Women’s Super League game earlier in March. Birmingham manager Carla Ward criticised the "thoughtless" and "ridiculous" timing which left her 20-year-old goalkeeper  " 90 minutes before she faced Everton. It is understood Riise did not send the emails. "The timing was not my call, but it was not how we want to work," Riise said. "That was a big mistake. As soon as we found out, I called both the coaches and Hannah [Hampton] to apologise for the process. That was a mistake that we don’t want to happen again." Norway great Riise, who  , has whittled down a shortlist of 35 players who remain in contention for a spot in the small 18-player Team GB squad for this summer’s Tokyo games. Before then, her focus will be on April’s England friendlies against France and Canada and on Tuesday she named a 24-player Lionesses squad. England captain Steph Houghton misses out with an Achilles injury, and Riise said Houghton was somebody you cannot replace but it was a chance for others "to step up". Forward Nikita Parris is also unavailable after several people tested positive for Covid-19 at her club side Lyon. That localised outbreak may yet hit April 9’s fixture against France in Caen, but it is not yet known how many of the French national side are affected. Riise added: "We don’t want to risk anything but our plan is to go to France and play. We haven’t heard anything different." Veteran goalkeepers Karen Bardsley and Carly Telford have both been recalled to the squad, while Birmingham’s Hampton misses out, with four shot-stoppers named in the squad, increasing from three in February. Manchester City No 1 Ellie Roebuck and Everton keeper Sandy MacIver remain in the squad alongside the returning Bardsley and Telford, while among the outfield players Chelsea’s versatile youngster Niamh Charles has been called up for the first time and might provide backup to Lucy Bronze at right-back. Bristol City's 20-year-old striker   misses out after her first call-up in February, while there is still no place for in-form  , nor Everton midfielder Izzy Christiansen. The absence of Houghton will be the most notable challenge for England to deal with. Manchester City’s 32-year-old skipper has earned 121 caps for her country and has been near ever-present for the Lionesses since being handed the armband by former head coach Mark Sampson in 2014. Midfielder Jill Scott, who collected her 150th cap last time out in   could be in line to wear the armband again, after being named captain for sentimental reasons for that landmark appearance. Fifa   could also be in contention, along with striker Ellen White and some younger names. "There will always be players that cannot come into due to injury and things we cannot control," Riise said. "But I feel like that’s a chance for others to step up. Steph’s been captain and a major player for a long time. We can’t replace her, but it’s an opportunity for a younger player to step up." At centre-back, England have vast options to choose from. Houghton’s injury could give Arsenal duo Leah Williamson and Lotte Wubben-Moy a chance to start at centre-back, either as a partnership or with one of them alongside Chelsea’s Millie Bright, while Manchester United’s Millie Turner could also push for a place. Manchester City left-back Demi Stokes has returned to the squad after injury, which may in turn provide yet another option at centre-back, because her club team-mate and fellow left-back   has proven herself to be equally capable of slotting in as a left-side centre-half. But with Houghton - if fit - among the few players surely certain of a space among the 18 for Tokyo, the upcoming England games will showcase the strong competition for places behind her.
