heading: Why Newcastle won't sack Steve Bruce despite their perilous Premier League position
subheading: As long as Bruce has the backing of owner Mike Ashley, he will be backed to pull Newcastle out of the mess they are in
author: Luke Edwards
article: Trying to make sense out of the nonsensical has been a consistent feature of Mike Ashley’s 14-year reign as Newcastle United owner. In fact, it would make a decent book title when it comes to assessing the damage his decisions have inflicted on a club trapped in a constant state of mediocrity and frustration. Even so, Ashley’s decision not to sack Steve Bruce as head coach following a   before the international break, that left the Magpies in clear and present danger of a third relegation to the Championship since 2009, is one of his most controversial calls. Bruce is the manager very few Newcastle supporters wanted when he replaced Rafa Benitez, just three weeks before the first game of the 2019/20 campaign. And nobody seems to have any faith in him to get them out of trouble 20 months later, with 95 per cent of the 12,000 supporters who took part in a survey by the Newcastle Chronicle, wanting Bruce to be removed in results published on Monday. After a run of two wins in 20 games that has left the Magpies just two points above the relegation zone, most clubs would have sacked Bruce, looking for a “new manager bounce” to try and lift them clear of the drop zone. Yet, Ashley has never listened to supporter angst and has not been bullied into making a decision, whether it concerns the running of his retail empire or his football club. It has always been done his way, rightly or wrongly, and that is not about to change.  Sources have indicated that while Bruce was stung by the result of the survey in the local paper he used to read growing up, they were dismissed as unhelpful noise by others at the club and ignored. So,  , given the almost universal opposition to his continued presence among supporters, as well as local media commentators? Newcastle have looked and sounded divided ever since colourful details of a training ground bust-up between Bruce and winger Matt Ritchie were leaked to a national newspaper earlier this month. There were claims that some players had given up on Bruce too and wanted him to be replaced. There were accusations that the squad were given too many days off and even suggestions in a series of follow-up attacks that Bruce was waiting to be sacked in order to receive his £4million pay off.  In reality, there are some players, mainly those who are not playing regularly, who have an axe to grind. Others remain both supportive and loyal to the manager and were furious about the leaks. Regardless, it was incendiary stuff and helped whip up opposition to Bruce to new levels of toxicity, even before the awful performance at Brighton. Ashley, though, took a rather different view and rather than sack his head coach, he has been inclined to back him even more. Not only because he likes Bruce and feels he has been treated unfairly by the local media on Tyneside, as well as fans, but because he expects more from the players too.  The perception is they have been content to hide behind an unpopular manager and avoid criticism of their own shortcomings and mistakes. The mantra this week has been play for the crest on the shirt. Nothing else should matter. From the moment the Ritchie bust-up story appeared in a national newspaper and was followed up by more negative leaks, Ashley took the view that Bruce had been betrayed by others he also employs. He was furious, as was managing director Lee Charnley and the other members of Ashley’s inner circle. They felt there was a concerted attempt from a person or people, acting purely out of self interest, looking to undermine the club, the team and, of course Bruce. At the precise time they were expected to pull together to get out of trouble, there were people intending to cause even more of it.  If the leaks and coverage were designed to enforce the removal of Bruce, it had the opposite effect. For the majority of fans, it is misguided loyalty from Ashley to the point of neglect, failing to realise that unless there is a change in the dugout, Newcastle will go down. Those around him have advised differently.  The attacks on both men have been severe and sustained. But Ashley will not be pressured into anything and Bruce will not resign, steadfastly believing he is the man to guide the team out of the mess he has got them into. It is a huge gamble. Nobody at St James’ Park is denying that privately, but it is the decision they have made.  When you have appointed a new manager in March and April before — Alan Shearer in 2009 and Rafa Benitez in 2016 — to try and avoid relegation and still gone down, why not stick this time and let things play out? The feeling is Newcastle may only need another nine or ten points from their remaining nine games to be safe and that, they feel, is achievable with Bruce in charge. For his part, Bruce has sounded too defeatist too often. His approach has lacked conviction. He has looked to shirk blame and has become embroiled in a battle with his critics in the media, coverage that has merely reflected supporter dismay at what has unfolded this season. Something has to change and at least his tone has. But tough, confident and abrasive talk needs to be reflected in performances. The players need to rally behind the manager, not hide. Much was made last week of the fact that the players had been given six days off in the international break and were not hauled into training on the Sunday after the Brighton capitulation.  That was due to Covid testing protocols, with testing pre-arranged for those players not on international duty later in the week.  But why were the players given additional days off — six in total during the international break — when they could have been preparing for this weekend’s game against Tottenham Hotspur? Interestingly, the report detailing the number of days off did concern the Newcastle hierarchy and an investigation was carried out, but the result of it may surprise Bruce’s many critics. Newcastle’s players have had fewer days off training this season than they have in each of the past five years at the same stage of the campaign and the data was there to prove it. It was also a schedule designed with the club’s specialist fitness and medical staff, with the view the players need to rest, both mentally and physically, is more important than ever after a summer without a break from football. The hope is the days off will help avoid any more fatigue related injuries this season. Like the decision not to sack Bruce, only time will tell if it was the right call or not.

heading: Transfer notebook: Manchester United's goalkeeper dilemma and Liverpool eye young France defender
subheading: Solskjaer is expected to stick with one goalkeeper, rather than regularly change, for the business end of the season
author: Mike McGrath
article: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer will now have to choose between Dean Henderson and David De Gea as Manchester United’s No 1 for the rest of the season after giving both a chance to impress.  Henderson played in six games before joining up with England for the international break, with De Gea granted time to return to Spain for the birth of his first child and requiring time to quarantine on his return.   With nine Premier League games left in the campaign and a place in the Champions League to secure, Solskjaer is expected to stick with one goalkeeper rather than regularly change for the business end of the season.  Henderson has staked a strong claim in the last month with clean sheets against Crystal Palace, Manchester City and West Ham. Simon Kjaer's goal for AC Milan in the Europa League could have been prevented but he kept the Italians out in the second leg.  He signed a new contract last summer when he returned from Sheffield United and was told he would get his chance at some point during the season. De Gea, who is approaching 10 years at Old Trafford, was picked for most of United’s Premier League games and has been publicly backed by Solskajer after mistakes.  De Gea’s contract has another two seasons to run with the option of a further year and his wages of around £350,000 a week would be the biggest obstacle for a club to look at buying him.  Liverpool will get the first run at signing Ibrahima Konaté from RB Leipzig this summer as their rivals have other priorities in the window.  Jurgen Klopp is the frontrunner for the France Under-21 centre-back and can move swiftly as he has no players to shift first before moving for a long-term centre-back.   Chelsea would look at selling one of their four first-team centre-backs before making a move for another defender, while Tottenham are in the same position.  Manchester United are looking signing a centre-back this summer but will look at other areas, including right wing, before deciding on a budget for alternative players.  Bulgaria forward Kiril Despodov is taking legal action against Cagliari over unpaid wages and wants a release from his contract.  The 24 year-old, who scored against Switzerland last week, will be a sought-after free agent if he is successful in his dispute with the Italian club.   Serie A clubs were given permission to pay players over 14 months last season due to the coronavirus pandemic but Despodov was told he was not entitled to wages for July and August after he returned from a loan.  “The dispute is pending in front of an Italian arbitration panel, with a decision expected shortly. Fifpro is closely following the matter,” read a statement from the world players’ union.  Luton Town striker James Collins is attracting interest with his contract due to expire at Kenilworth Road in the summer.  The 30 year-old has helped his club to two promotions and has reached double figures for goals in his two seasons in the Championship. Preston and Derby are among a host of clubs who are monitoring his situation but there is also interest from MLS clubs in America.

heading: Rating the F1 teams after the Bahrain GP: Are Red Bull fastest and are Aston Martin in trouble?
subheading: We dive deep into the data from the opening round to see which teams will be happy and which teams are facing a potential nightmare season
author: Luke Slater
article: The 2021 Formula One season is underway with a bang after arguably the  . For the first time since 2018 Mercedes have genuine competition at the front, this time from Red Bull. It is promising for a captivating season ahead and a  . But are Red Bull actually the quickest team? Will Mercedes and Hamilton need to be at the very top of their game just to compete, as was the case on Sunday? And what about the rest of the grid? Now that we've had a decent amount of competitive running, it is a little easier to see the overall picture.  We have carefully sifted through the numbers and data to work out who the real winners and losers of F1's opening weekend were, and what this means for the season ahead.  As well as qualifying and race performance, we looked at a team's overall position as well as their progress relative to a) their average last season and b) the first race last year. We have combined this to create a progress percentage on their raw pace.  The overall rankings, then, are as much a chart of improvement as anything, rather than the "correct" order. So, who should be quietly confident and who is facing a long season ahead? Even on the limited running we have seen so far, Haas look to be in a similar position to Williams in 2019. That is to say they will be hopelessly adrift of even the second slowest team for the entirety of the year.  Given that they say they are not developing the current VF21 at all this season and the fact that they have two rookies   and Nikita Mazepin, this will be a long and painful season. The primary aim will be to bring their young drivers up to speed but with so little experience behind the wheel of a car that looks problematic, you have to question the wisdom of this.  No team has moved further back since 2020 and that is likely to be the direction of travel throughout 2021, too.   -1.050% (10th) There is still a long way to go yet but this has been a troubling start to the  . As Racing Point last season they were probably the third quickest team, on balance, with their Mercedes W10 imitation. And just like the actual Mercedes team this year, there is no doubt they have moved backwards in the order.  Despite Lance Stroll making it into final qualifying, Aston Martin were the seventh quickest team in Bahrain on raw pace behind the usual back three of Alfa Romeo, Williams and Haas. They are some way down on their 2020 level, with midfield rivals McLaren, AlphaTauri and Ferrari all making progress of varying degrees.  Their race showing was a little better but they now face a dilemma. Ideally the 2022 regulation changes – and F1’s new era – should be the focus of their resources, but with a start this poor the team may need to put their efforts into making this car better or face a demoralising season. Force India were very good at in-season improvement and that quality looks needed here.   -0.404% (8th) The team formerly known as Renault now have Fernando Alonso at the helm. He did his best throughout the Bahrain Grand Prix, but the A521 looked sluggish. Esteban Ocon did not fare much better, either, finishing a lap down in 13th and behind both Alfa Romeo cars. The team have made absolute progress from last year (only three teams did not) but their relative progress – which is more important – is backwards.  Again, like Aston Martin they face the “development dilemma”. No team wants to struggle outside the points for an entire year, going backwards and not forwards. But resource may be best spent on working on their 2022 car.  There is still a chance that the team and drivers can understand the car and its behaviour better as the season goes on, but you do wonder if the Renault power unit is the primary cause of its lack of pace. In   we said that the window for Alpine this year could be anywhere between third and seventh. With McLaren, Alfa Romeo, Ferrari and AlphaTauri all on the up, seventh looks the more likely outcome.   +0.167% (7th) With new owners and  , the hopes at Williams would have been to continue their progress and turn it into something tangible; creating a car that can occasionally score points. On the showing in Bahrain they may have moved forward a little in overall performance but they sit in a similar place to 2020, albeit moving ahead of Haas in the order.  George Russell again made it into Q2 whilst team-mate Nicholas Latifi did not. This could be a common theme again in 2021. On everything we have seen so far, Williams risk being caught in no man’s land in ninth place – well ahead of Haas behind but well behind of whoever is ahead, whether Alfa Romeo, Aston Martin or Alpine.  +0.516% (5th)  It appears that the new aero regulations for 2021 have affected Mercedes and Racing Point – with their low-rake philosophy – more than the other teams. This, combined with Red Bull making a big step forward with their car’s stability and overall performance, has set up a mouthwatering season ahead.  Ninth in the overall progress chart looks worse than it is , but that is largely due to a stellar season in 2020. The only way was down after that.  It will be interesting to see whether they focus much on developing the W12 or look towards next year. Still, unlike the smaller teams, they should have the resource to do both. Clearly, there are still some issues. Although the car looked a match for Red Bull in the hands of Hamilton in the race, a gap of four-tenths in qualifying will be a little concerning, even with 22 rounds left in the championship.   -0.435% (9th) After pre-season testing there was a hint that McLaren could have moved ahead of the midfield pack. On the weekend’s showing it does not look like they have managed that yet, with only a small absolute improvement from last year. This should not be cause for concern.  Their biggest concern will be looking at the teams directly behind them with Ferrari resurgent and AlphaTauri on the up, too. Their consistent pace and performances throughout a season were their strengths in 2020 and it should be the same this time, especially with Lando Norris and Daniel Ricciardo on board.   +0.160% (6th) Alfa Romeo top the progress charts, having made a huge step forward in raw pace from both their 2020 overall time and their performance in the first race of last season. For most of last year they were cut adrift with Haas and Williams but this year there should be much more chance of success: that is to say points.  Perhaps the Ferrari power unit has helped but Alfa Romeo will be one of the teams most pleased with their performance so far. Despite being the eighth fastest team in Bahrain – where they were last year –   it is not out of the question that they could prove obstacles for Alpine and Aston Martin in the next few races and beyond.   +1.331% (1st)  Like McLaren, Ferrari would have had hopes that they could leap ahead of the midfield pack on their own. Like McLaren, that does not look to be the case. After pre-season testing there were questions over whether they might even struggle to improve all that much on last year’s dismal showing. First impressions, however, look decent.  Charles Leclerc showed the car’s potential with fourth in qualifying, just a couple of tenths behind Valtteri Bottas in the second Mercedes. Carlos Sainz could have been closer too, but did not nail his Q3 lap. Sixth and eighth in the final reckoning is hardly reason to crack out the bubbly but given that this is a track which rewards power, then Ferrari can feel cautiously optimistic about the season ahead. It will be a tight fight with McLaren, but third place is a target.   +0.763% (4th)  Red Bull can leave Bahrain disappointed but happy overall. Their pre-season pace was not an illusion and they begin the season with the fastest car and a man capable of delivering the best from it in Max Verstappen. The worry will be whether they can keep up with Mercedes – or keep them at bay in qualifying – for very long.  The 0.388secs that separated Verstappen and Hamilton in qualifying was significant. But the performance gap between Red Bull and Mercedes was, well, almost impossible to call even after 56 laps. With so many races this year and a huge variety of tracks, it is likely we will see the order see-sawing but, whatever, the RB16B looks a seriously impressive car and already arguably their best of the turbo-hybrid era.  Development throughout the season has usually been their strong point. It has had to be, as the team have been painfully slow starters. The giants they have to fell in Hamilton and Mercedes are now within touching distance, but it appears that it will take a monumental effort to down them.  +0.782% (3rd) It might seem strange to have a team that only scored two points with one ninth place at the top of this list. That was the case with Racing Point after the first race of last year and it is the same with AlphaTauri this year. Their potential is enormous, but they did not deliver on it on Sunday.  Pierre Gasly has always gone well in Bahrain but qualifying fifth is a fantastic result. Yuki Tsunoda could have been up there as well – and he looks a serious prospect – but for a mistake in Q2. Gasly made contact with Daniel Ricciardo early on and that ruined his race, but it is not an exaggeration to say that they could cause headaches for Ferrari and McLaren this year on current form.  Going by the data, the Honda engine seems to be a massive upgrade on last year’s, which should serve them well. Aerodynamically the car – like its sister at Red Bull – appears compliant to the drivers’ will. There are many reasons to be excited for the Italian team this year.   +0.972% (2nd)

heading: The truth about why Wojciech Szczesny left Arsenal
subheading: Sold by Arsenal for just £10m, Poland goalkeeper Szczesny is now Juventus' No 1 and Frank Lampard showed an interest last summer
author: Matt Law,
article: Wojciech Szczesny had  out of the Roma team for an entire season when Arsenal’s former transfer chief Dick Law delivered the news he had not wanted to hear. Despite spending two years on loan at Roma, Szczesny had bought a new house in the Totteridge area of Barnet and had not given up on resuming his career at the Emirates. But Law told him that he would be third choice behind Petr Cech and David Ospina under manager Arsene Wenger, leaving the Pole no choice but to seek a permanent move away from Arsenal and his performances in Italy earned him a transfer to Juventus. That was four years ago and Szczesny will return to England on Wednesday night with the Poland squad as the man who has kept both Alisson and Gianluigi Buffon on the sidelines, and stopped Juventus spending big on Gianluigi Donnarumma. He has also started Poland’s last two games, against Hungary and Andorra, ahead of his former Arsenal team-mate Lukasz Fabianski.  It was only a year after Juventus signed Szczesny for £10million that Liverpool made his old Roma understudy Alisson the world’s most expensive goalkeeper by signing him for £66.8m before  Arsenal, it could be claimed, had not judged the market well and it was in the summer of 2018 that Szczesny was officially given the task of succeeding arguably the best goalkeeper of all-time in Turin, as Buffon joined Paris Saint-Germain, and he has not looked back. “In Roma, I put on the bench the best goalkeeper in the world, in Juventus the best in history,” said Szczesny in 2019. “It turns out that I am the best in the world and in history!” Szczesny was clearly joking, but he has certainly developed into one of the best goalkeepers in the world which is reflected by the fact that the last contract he signed with Juventus put him second only to  And while the disappointing performances of Juventus in the Champions League have perhaps prevented Szczesny getting some of the credit outside Italy that he has deserved, those within the game are well aware of his talent. Former Chelsea head coach Frank Lampard showed an interest in trying to bring Szczesny back to England last summer, before the Blues signed Edouard Mendy, but, having learned the language and quickly settled into the lifestyle, the 30-year-old could not be happier in Italy. In his second season at Roma, Szcesny kept the most clean sheets in Serie A, as Alisson watched from the bench, and after taking over from Buffon he earned a nomination for the Yashin Trophy - the prize to recognise the world’s best goalkeeper over the course of the campaign. Last season, Szczesny won his third Serie A title with Juventus and was named the best goalkeeper in Italy. But perhaps the greatest acknowledgement of Szczesny’s performances was the fact that Buffon, on returning to the club, turned down his offer to take back his old number one shirt and instead insisted on wearing the number 77 in recognition of the fact he was no longer first-choice. Just how and why Arsenal let one of the world’s best goalkeepers slip through their fingers for a relative pittance remains a sore point among some of the club’s supporters, even allowing for some poor moments of judgement on and off the pitch and a confidence in his own ability that could border on arrogance. Having kept 16 clean sheets, Szczesny finished the 2013-14 season as the joint holder of the Premier League’s Golden Glove award with Cech, who was still at Chelsea, and had delighted Arsenal fans by posting a video of himself playing ‘We won the League at White Hart Lane’ on the piano the day after a North London derby victory over Tottenham Hotspur. But problems started to pile up in the following campaign, as Szczesny conceded a penalty and was sent-off in a Champions League game against Galatasaray, and was caught smoking in the changing-room showers after making mistakes for both of the goals in a defeat to Southampton. Szczesny was fined £20,000 and lost his Premier League place to Ospina following the smoking incident, but it was not just a crafty cigarette and a couple of mistakes that had annoyed Wenger. Not satisfied with the training methods of Wenger’s trusted goalkeeping coach Gerry Peyton, Szczesny would arrive at Arsenal’s London Colney training ground at 7am to go through a session with one of the club’s other coaches - something the Frenchman disapproved of. The clash of personalities between Szczesny and Peyton was laid bare in an interview filmed in Poland, in which the goalkeeper appeared with his international team-mate Fabianski, who has also been a success at Swansea City and West Ham United since leaving the Emirates on a free transfer when his contract expired in 2014. Describing a video analysis session that Peyton put on for Arsenal’s goalkeepers at the time, Szczesny said: “We’re going not knowing what it will be about, right? And it’s a four to five minute video of goals that I let past me, but could have done better.” Fabianski added: “It’s only Szczesny goals though. They were only Szczesny’s mistakes, but there was us and Vito (Vito Mannone) and maybe Emi (Emiliano Martinez) watching.” Szczesny finished by saying: “So, we’re watching, but we don’t know what is going on. It’s just showing errors, he (Peyton) is not explaining anything. So the video ends and Gerry says ‘See, you’re not perfect’. And that was it. We’re all looking at each other like ‘oh’.” He may not have been perfect, but there have not been many better than Szczesny since Wenger decided that he was not even Arsenal’s second-best goalkeeper.

heading: Lewis Hamilton exceeded track limits nearly 30 times - so why was Max Verstappen punished?
subheading: Verstappen and Hamilton's issues were fundamentally different, but both men were right to feel confused at the FIA's inconsistency
author: Luke Slater
article: Sunday’s   delivered all that and more than F1 fans would have expected. Lewis Hamilton held off a charging Max Verstappen in the closing laps to take a stunning victory and, for the first time in some years, it looks like we have a   on our hands.  Yet there was still plenty of debate and controversy in how the rules over “track limits” were being enforced. We break down what took place below.  It was ultimately a culmination of issues which led to confusion in the middle of the race and Verstappen handing back the lead to Hamilton within moments of taking it. However, these are two separate issues.   One was drivers running off the track on the exit of turn four, meaning they could carry more speed through the corner apex and define the track in a more favourable way to gain lap time. This was monitored and punished in qualifying, but not the race – at least initially.  Hamilton repeatedly left the track at turn four before being warned not to by his team or he would run the risk of a five-second penalty. Verstappen tried to avoid leaving the track at turn four – as he thought it was not permitted – and did so until his team informed him that Mercedes were consistently doing so and were not being penalised. He then changed his approach.  The second issue was Verstappen completing his overtake of Hamilton off the track, which is not legal. But should the Dutchman have given the position back, or charged off ahead and tried to negate a potential five or 10-second penalty? Initially, the Race Directors’ notes ahead of the weekend simply read: “The track limits at the exit of Turn 4 will not be monitored with regard to setting a lap time, as the defining limits are the artificial grass and the gravel trap in that location.”  However, this was later updated (after first practice) to: “A lap time achieved during any practice session by leaving the track and cutting behind the red and white kerb on the exit of Turn 4, will result in that lap time being invalidated by the stewards.” It was made clear that previous note about them not being monitored only applied to the race, and drivers and teams were also referred to Article 27.3 of the Sporting Regulations.  This states: “Drivers must make every reasonable effort to use the track at all times and may not leave the track without a justifiable reason”.  “Should a car leave the track the driver may re-join… without gaining any lasting advantage. At the absolute discretion of the Race Director a driver may be given the opportunity to give back the whole of any advantage he gained by leaving the track.” A “lasting” advantage clearly refers to position, as a small lap time advantage on its own is not lasting. A single lap time advantage repeated over 30-odd laps though? That is an interesting question and perhaps one which belatedly occurred to Race Control in the middle of the race, forcing them into action.  On Monday, the FIA Race Director Michael Masi confirmed that the overtaking incident involving Verstappen was “quite different” to Hamilton’s repeated transgressions of track limits, and thus was judged accordingly. According to Reuters, Masi said that Verstappen breached the sporting regulations which are always in force regardless of pre-race briefings because the Dutchman “gained a lasting advantage by overtaking another car off the racetrack”. Masi also confirmed that he directly told Red Bull to order Verstappen to return first place to Hamilton immediately after he had put all four wheels outside the track limits. During the race, Verstappen was frustrated when he was told that Hamilton and Bottas were frequently exceeding track limits at turn four. “How is that legal, man? The whole weekend we couldn’t do it,” he said. He also immediately questioned his team’s decision to tell him to let Hamilton by. “Why didn’t you just let me go? I could have easily pulled those five [penalty] seconds,” Verstappen said. “I’d prefer to lose a win like that than be second like this.” “We had the instruction from race control unfortunately Max,” team principal Christian Horner replied.  However, once he was out of the car his position had mellowed. Immediately after the race, he said “I knew that I ran out of the track limits, yeah, and then at turn eight they told me, so I gave the position back out of 10. It is what it is.” By the time he went into the post-race press conference with the written press, he had accepted that it was the right thing to do to give the place back to Hamilton.  Remarkably, he even said that he did not give it back on the pit straight as it would have been “unfair”, because he would have had a better chance to overtake on the second straight with the aid of DRS.  After the race, Horner expressed frustration at the grey area of track limits and its enforcement in Bahrain.  Hamilton reacted with dismay when he was told during the race to stay inside track limits at turn four or risk a penalty.  “I thought there were no track limits… I have been doing the same thing all race,” he said.  In fairness, he had a point – he was not aware that they would be enforcing this so strictly, or even at all. An onboard video shows he   before he was warned by his race engineer to stop.  After the race he described the situation as “confusing” and said that the FIA “changed their minds” half-way through the race, before adding that it ultimately helped extend his tyre life and that he was “grateful” for the call.  Verstappen giving the lead back to Hamilton is fair enough. It was an illegal overtake and, thankfully, his actions saved us from a thrilling race being (again) decided in the stewards’ room hours after the chequered flag fell.  Could Red Bull have let him try and get five seconds ahead? At that point it may have been possible, but it looked like he would soon have another opportunity to pass Hamilton. That was not the case, as his car struggled in Hamilton’s dirty air. Before passing Hamilton on lap 53 he was roughly 0.5secs a lap quicker, so it seems unlikely he could have made the five seconds in four laps.  The bigger issue comes with the inconsistency in how track limits were being applied to the drivers, with Red Bull and Mercedes taking differing approaches throughout the race.  It seems Red Bull were wrong and Mercedes right in the first instance. Red Bull should have been wiser here. Track limits at turn four were not going to be enforced during the race, other than with overtaking. That much was clear, or so they thought.  Red Bull first changed tack after seeing Mercedes running wide but then Mercedes told Hamilton to rein it in after being warned by Race Control. So, what changed in the middle of the race? Was it Hamilton’s repeated “infringements”? But infringements of what – track limits were, at that point, not being enforced.  Clearly, much better communication and action must be in place for future races. It would perhaps be best to err on the side of caution and stop drivers running off the track and then stick to it.  It is a terrible look to have a clear, written note to say that track limits would not be enforced in the race, only to start to enforce it half-way through the race when drivers continue to take advantage of it. What did they think would happen? Hopefully a lesson will be learned.

heading: Liverpool remain in hunt for centre-back - but what kind of defender are they looking for?
subheading: Jurgen Klopp's side are endeavouring to ensure they never find themselves in same situation that decimated their title ambitions this season
author: Chris Bascombe
article: Clubs tend to be reluctant to make promises before a transfer window, but there is one guarantee at Liverpool: Jurgen Klopp will be signing a centre-back this summer. Given  , that underlines how desperate those final hours were in January when the sense of emergency meant   and Preston North End’s Ben Davies ought to have been driven into the training ground at full speed in a police car with the siren screeching. In the subsequent months, those deals have looked even more of an expedient means to an end. No sooner was Kabak measuring up for his jersey than it was emphasised his loan spell does not include an obligation to buy - the inference being Liverpool are more hopeful than certain of the Turkish youngster’s long-term status. At £2 million Davies, still to make his debut, was cheap enough to buy in the knowledge that if he does not make the step up Anfield, his fee will be recouped later. Davies may be reassured by Klopp comparing the start of his Liverpool career to   - the Scotland skipper rarely seen for six months and trying to dislodge Alberto Moreno before making the position his. Even if we finally get a glimpse of Davies in the next two months, realistically the best he can hope for when the cavalry returns is to be fifth choice, presumably waiting for a Carabao Cup or FA Cup tie if a desirable loan move does not grab his or the club’s attention first. Even that will depend on  , or (as seems more likely) uses his promotion this season as a platform to become first choice elsewhere. Neither Kabak nor Davies can be under any illusions about their position in the pecking order once Virgil van Dijk, Joel Matip and Joe Gomez emerge from their long rehabilitation. Neither could they turn down an opportunity which would never have arisen but for the senior defenders’ injuries. Liverpool’s attempts to sign others in the same window is proof January was the antithesis of how they and other clubs prefer to operate - it was all about an attempted quick fix because more desirable targets were unavailable or (because of the inflated valuations mid-season) unaffordable. Had Croatian Duje Caleta-Car been allowed to leave Marseille for Anfield rather than stuck on a runway on a private plane which never took off, it may not be so certain Liverpool would again be scouring the market for defenders. The same could be said if the price for Brighton’s Ben White was not so prohibitive, especially as his club was never going to sanction a deal in the midst of a relegation fight. Liverpool also like  , while on Monday it emerged RB Leipzig’s Ibrahima Konate is among those under serious consideration, especially as he has a £35 million buy-out clause in his contract, thus reducing the need for a prolonged negotiation. That kind of price will seem even more attractive if alternatives are quoted at £50 million-plus by reluctant sellers. The credentials, value and availability of these players remains under assessment, so Liverpool insist they have made no decision yet on who they will most actively pursue and sign. As last summer proved, Liverpool are not averse to conducting negotiations simultaneously as they bid for left-back Jamal Lewis (then at Norwich) a matter of days before signing Olympiacos’ Kostas Tsimikas, and waited to see how firm Watford’s stance was on Ismaila Sarr’s valuation before deciding he was too expensive and finalising terms for Wolves’ Diogo Jota. On the surface, the fact Liverpool are openly looking for alternatives beyond their current squad does not bode well for Kabak and his chances of retaining his shirt beyond this summer.  When asked about that recently, Klopp was non-committal. That public stance is unlikely to change with the youngster preparing for the biggest few months of his career with Liverpool’s Champions League quarter-final against Real Madrid and the European Championships with his country.  Kabak made an indifferent start to his Liverpool career,  . Klopp will want him motivated by the enduring hope of making his temporary move permanent rather than deflated by the idea he is already fighting a lost cause staying beyond the summer. That may partially explain why even if Liverpool were to strike a deal behind the scenes they may see little value in confirming anything while their on-loan centre-back still has so much to play for.   What is clear is Liverpool are endeavouring to ensure they never find themselves in the same situation that decimated their Premier League ambitions in 2020/21. There are plenty who saw an accident-in-waiting by going into this campaign with only three senior centre-backs. Others believe retrospective wisdom has been applied because to lose all three to long-term injuries is unprecedented. But after a year of makeshift centre-backs, Klopp can plan to have four top-class ones to choose from next August, thus ensuring he no longer has to re-accommodate Fabinho and Jordan Henderson in the role.  once Klopp has the luxury of having several high-class and fully --fit candidates fighting for the right to partner van Dijk, rather than the unenviable and impossible one of filling the Grand Canyon-sized hole in his absence.

Whatever your allegiance in this year’s Six Nations, you cannot say it was a dull championship. It was one of the most discussed and most entertaining tournaments in recent memory with some critiques being germane and others inapposite. The truth is, Italy aside, and whatever the final table standings, the other five teams were separated by the finest of margins. With a different decision here or a play coming off there, it could all have looked so different. Analysing what went right and wrong for the teams, you must look at more than their finishing positions. Any talk of Wales being lucky champions is nonsense.   and created and converted more of their opportunities. Their experienced players returned to form and their blooded youngsters successfully negotiated the challenge of stepping up from club to international rugby. The work done by Wayne Pivac as head coach and assistants Jonathan Humphreys, Stephen Jones and Gethin Jenkins meant that, in defence and attack,   and makes them difficult to beat. Wales’ progress was an all-round effort, the challenge now being to maintain the upward curve all the way to 2023. There is nothing to suggest they cannot do this, other than the retirement of the talismanic Alun Wyn Jones. That he will retire is certain; that he will be seamlessly replaced, less so. Let us not carp about who did what, got sent off or benefited from a refereeing mistake, Wales are worthy champions. Of the chasing nations, Scotland and Ireland have a lot more to be pleased about than France and England. Scotland’s fourth place was scant reward in a season  . What must irk head coach Gregor Townsend is knowing that, with a tad more discipline, without a couple of aberrant acts, the one- and three-point losses to Wales and Ireland respectively could have been reversed and a Grand Slam claimed. They did not deserve to beat Ireland, but the chance was there, nonetheless. As with all the sides, the issue of discipline, at crucial points in games, is something Scotland must master. Their pack is now solid, and they have an array of attacking talent better and deeper than at any time in the professional era. The back three of Stuart Hogg, Sean Maitland or Darcy Graham, and Duhan van der Merwe is the equal of nearly any side in the world. France’s performances ebbed with each round and if the Covid-19 situation and postponed Scotland game affected them, they have only themselves to blame. In Antoine Dupont they have a gem and at least they were able to see several bench players prove they can handle this level of rugby. That said, the return of indiscipline and insouciance undercut France’s efforts and the glamour and style they are capable of was only sporadic. Every game involving France was worth watching and they  . Neither of their losses was overwhelming, but they did not achieve what their talent and squad depth promised. Head coach Fabien Galthie does not need to worry unduly, but nor can he be comfortable with the limited gains his side made in finishing second. England cannot honestly claim  . There are reasons, not excuses, for their poor showing – a Covid-limited squad and undercooked players being the chief issues. You then must look at Eddie Jones’ inflexibility in selection and the struggle to find a style that modifies the previously successful strategy of kicking on the front foot, as a first-choice option. Both added to their woes but there is another issue that is paramount. The fact that they conceded the same number of penalties as Italy is damning. No side can hope to win close games against top-class opposition if they cannot solve this problem and it is not new. They have been pilloried in the media and in public and cannot complain about some of the comments. I would, however, point out that the same people who now shout loudest about their decline did the same in 2018 – and look how that turned out. They have not become a bad side in one competition, but they have many issues to rectify, in an ever-shortening window, before the next World Cup.

heading: Justin Cochrane a strong contender for England Under-21 job
subheading: Cochrane has previously worked at Tottenham Hotspur and coached through the England youth levels
author: Jason Burt,
article: Justin Cochrane has emerged as a strong candidate should  Boothroyd’s contract expires this summer and the Football Association is considering whether it is time to make a change. The Under-21s are on the verge of exiting the European Championships having been beaten by Switzerland and Portugal, failing to register a shot on target, in what has, so far, been another dismal campaign. Their final group game is against Croatia on Wednesday with England needing a two-goal victory and help from elsewhere - otherwise they will be out. England   and the pressure on Boothroyd to go would be overwhelming. The FA may decide it is time for a change come what may. If Boothroyd leaves the task of replacing him will fall to John McDermott, the FA’s new technical director, although there is also expected to be   who was Boothroyd’s predecessor. Boothroyd has been in charge since 2016, promoted from his role with the Under-20s, and the FA will consider internal and external candidates as part of a shortlist. The highly-rated Cochrane is likely to feature prominently and is well-known to McDermott having previously worked with him at Tottenham Hotspur where he was assistant head of development (11-16) and went on to coach at Under-23 level at the Premier League club. The 39-year-old was appointed England Under-15s coach and then moved through the age groups to take charge of the Under-16s and then Under-17s. A former international with Antigua and Barbuda, London-born Cochrane started his playing career at Queens Park Rangers although he made his most appearances with Crewe Alexandra before dropping into non-league football. However the former midfielder has built a strong reputation within the FA through his coaching ability and is likely to be shortlisted as a replacement for Boothroyd. During a discussion last year on ending white privilege in football and the lack of BAME representation Southgate described Cochrane as potentially “top coach” and it appears that view is shared throughout the FA. Southgate has argued that more “forceful change” is needed. “We have some very good young black coaches coming through our development teams, Justine Cochrane is somebody who I think, within our group of national coaches, he is going to be a top coach,” Southgate said. “We also shouldn’t look just at the ex-players or high-profile players because as we know, so many of the top managers haven’t been top top international players and that route must also be open to black coaches that haven’t played at the highest level.” Even if Cochrane does not succeed Boothroyd it appears he is likely to be interviewed for the post and could be part of the new set-up for the Under-21s.

Apparently my mobile phone is quite a sophisticated gadget. It can make and receive calls, track my speed and location, allow me to manage my overdraft, and even control my central heating from anywhere in the world (this last one still amazes me on a regular basis). But for the past few months it has fulfilled a far simpler function, acting as a portal to a world that seemed so far away yet is now tantalisingly   Sunday League football. There is one particular video on my phone that my wife would file for divorce if she knew how many times I had grubbily watched it; every occasion during lockdown that I felt at my lowest, snuck into the bathroom, pulled my phone out and gave myself a visual dopamine hit. It is an 18-second clip taken last October, during that all-too-brief period we naively assumed life had returned to something resembling normality. The stage is Victoria Park, London, where two amateur football teams - one of them mine - are battling in a knockout cup tie. It is early in the second half and the ball is bouncing around on the left flank about 35 yards from goal. Suddenly, with a nonchalance earned through decades of firing Sunday League blanks and therefore having precisely zero expectations of what is about to unfold, our striker Joel controls it with his right foot and casually unleashes hell with his left. Improbably, the camera is positioned at the perfect angle directly behind him. His shot rises, dips, beats the diving goalkeeper, crashes off the crossbar and goes in. Think Papiss Cisse for Newcastle United against Chelsea in 2012. Then picture the scene as a dozen squad members (there was a hefty supporting cast that day) lose their minds on the touchline like a group of five-year-olds told to run riot in a soft-play centre. It is beautiful mayhem; pure child-like ecstasy that, for more than three dismal, dreary, depressing months of lockdown, has been missing. In recent weeks, I have been down to my local park on a few occasions and kicked a ball with a friend. It has, given the circumstances, been bliss. Pumping up the ball, lacing up the Copa Mundial boots, needlessly putting on a replica shirt, and repeatedly failing to kick the ball in the air further than 20 yards. It has been a crumb of footballing comfort in bleak times. I cannot wait to be beaten by an opposition winger again, limply challenge for a header or pass the ball straight out of play. I cannot wait to be riled by a patently incorrect offside decision. More than that, I cannot wait to play as a team. To see Radu, our chain-smoking Romanian goalkeeper who comes straight from working the night shift; Wicksy, the best canal boat-habiting amateur footballer in the south; Mario, who resolutely refuses to buy a mobile phone or computer and can only be contacted via landline. To walk out with Ben Q, who has invariably not been to bed; Faz, who retires from football on a fortnightly basis; Joe H, who can kick a ball further than the rest of us combined. The names will be different up and down the country - Faz might be Mark, Radu might be Sarah, Wicksy might be JP - but for thousands of people, this week has heralded the return of something so much bigger than simply kicking or throwing a ball. I was recently asked a hypothetical question about what professional sport I would like any children I have to play. Without a moment’s hesitation I suggested anything played as part of a team. Within my football team, ages range from 25 to 58. I have been on football tours with all of them and yet I do not know most of their partners’ names. We have a shared bond that is much more important than winning or losing. It is not the act of making a last-ditch slide tackle I miss, but what it means for everyone. That game in which Joel scored his wonder goal finished 2-2 after normal time and we ended up losing it on penalties. Despite being knocked out of the cup, defeat was irrelevant. I was not even playing that day, but it remains my favourite ever amateur football match. It got me through lockdown. Finally, we can make new memories again.

“Agueroooooo”. There are some moments in football that need little by way of explanation. Utter Martin Tyler’s simple but immortal line for that   on that sun-soaked afternoon at the Etihad Stadium and anyone with a reasonable interest in football will know instantly what you are talking about. It was, and is, the most famous goal in Premier League history and something truly extraordinary is going to have to happen to ever supplant it from that position. After a 44-year wait to be reacquainted with the championship, that goal would be cemented in Manchester City folklore whatever the circumstances. That it snatched the title away on goal difference from the club in whose shadow City had not so much lived as suffered and almost become defined by for two decades was a fairy tale that not even the most imaginative supporter could have dreamt up. Manchester United and Sir Alex Ferguson were almost breaking out into celebration at Sunderland’s Stadium of Light when Aguero received Mario Balotelli’s pass, nicked the ball past Taye Taiwo after the slightest of feints and thundered home a finish. The clock said 93:20 - a time so iconic they ended up naming a suite at the Etihad after it. You had to be inside the stadium that day to fully appreciate the noise and delirium that ensued - and the kaleidoscope of emotions among supporters, many of whom had been pouring out of the exit doors 10 minutes before Aguero pounced. I do not subscribe to the view that City would never have recovered had they blown the title that day - the owners are too rich, the project too good - but it may have set the whole thing back a couple of years, if not longer, and invited a fresh torrent of “cups for cock-ups” taunts. Had Aguero missed, it could have had other consequences, too - it might even have seen Ferguson retire that summer, 12 months before he finally bowed out. David Gill, the former United chief executive, once told me he had never seen Ferguson lower than that summer and, for a while, even he seemed unsure if the Scot was going to be able to summon the energy to return again the next season and fight to win the title back. And that was a man who had already won 12 of the things. Imagine how City would have felt? So it is totally reasonable to say Aguero provided the foundation for the success that was to follow, that he unlocked the key bequeathed by Sheikh Mansour’s largesse.  in England although, in truth, you did not have to wait until the giddy denouement of that breathless campaign to realise City had someone special in their midst. His two-goal debut against Swansea on Aug 15, 2011 was one of the finest in the competition’s history, despite only running for half an hour, and he only needed another two games to plunder his first hat-trick against a Wigan Athletic side who simply did not know what had hit them. He would end up with 12 Premier League hat-tricks - surpassing Alan Shearer’s record last year - although whether there is a lucky 13th to come between now and his departure in May remains to be seen. You sense Aguero would settle for one more big, defining goal, given that it seems unrealistic to think he is going to get a lot of minutes over the next two months after so little football in the past year. It is curious that we still know so comparatively little about a man who has spent a decade on these shores but then there is something appealingly old-fashioned about Aguero’s unfussy pursuit of goals, goals and more goals. He’s like the Argentine Paul Scholes - it’s about the game and the game only for him and if there’s a back door out of the stadium to make a quick getaway and escape the media throngs then rest assured he will find it. The two would probably get on well. Aguero has never sought to encourage the sort of mystique that formed around the flamboyant Eric Cantona. He never courted controversy like Luis Suarez. He has not had the profile of Thierry Henry, who gave us “va-va-voom” on and off the pitch. He never declared an ambition to become the world’s greatest footballer, like Cristiano Ronaldo, even if, for a while, his old manager at City, Manuel Pellegrini, was convinced Aguero was the planet’s best after the Portuguese and Lionel Messi. Hell, he does not even have a trademark goal celebration. Even Shearer, who celebrated Blackburn’s title triumph in 1995 by creosoting his fence, had one of those. Indeed, one of the most revealing and touching parts of Amazon’s All Or Nothing documentary charting City’s 2017-18 title-winning season was when the cameras went into Aguero’s home and found a man living a rather lonely existence. But for a monthly visit from his son Benjamin, or the occasional hang out with Nicolas Otamendi or David De Gea, Aguero admitted he spent a lot of his spare time watching mafia and action films - just not horror movies that might scare a man living on his own. Part of you just wanted to wrap him up and bring him home in that moment. Perhaps they are some of the factors behind why some may hesitate to call Aguero the Premier League’s best ever striker, and maybe that would be a step too far, but he has more goals in the competition than any overseas player and the best goals-per-minute ratio of anyone. And, as with David Silva and Vincent Kompany, two other City greats who, like Aguero, will soon be immortalised in statues outside the Etihad, the Argentine will not be easily replaced, off the field let alone on it. That said, you wondered for a while if Pep Guardiola was completely sold at first. Aguero, like Carlos Tevez before him, was one of those strikers who would hold back in training, saving himself for matchday, and for a character like Guardiola that was not always easy to accept. But the Catalan came to appreciate and admire Aguero in a way everyone else did and, with the arrival of Gabriel Jesus, provided the stimulus that would help lift the Argentine’s level again. There have been four Premier League titles, one FA Cup and five League Cups and there could be another batch of silverware to follow over the final instalment of his City career. Perhaps the club will yet reach the Champions League final and Aguero will come off the bench to clinch the winner in Istanbul on May 29. Maybe, just maybe, there is another ‘Aguerooooo’ moment to come. It would certainly be a fitting bookend. With 181 Premier League goals, Sergio Aguero sits fourth in the all-time list behind Alan Shearer (260), Wayne Rooney (208) and Andy Cole (187). And you wouldn’t bet against him moving past Cole in Manchester City’s final eight league games of the season. When the 33 year-old departs the Etihad after their last game against Everton, the debate will rage over the Argentine hitman’s place among the all-time greats. Arguably the one downside for Aguero to playing alongside the likes of Vincent Kompany, Yaya Toure, David Silva and Kevin de Bruyne has been he’s never been the outright main man at City. In the five seasons between 2014 and 2019, Aguero scored more than 20 goals each time but only in the final two was he named in the PFA Team of the Year. He never won the PFA, FWA and Premier League Player of the Year awards and it all leads to the feeling that despite his efficiency in front of goal, blistering speed, power at his peak and uncanny ability to deliver in the biggest moments, he is not truly valued outside of the blue half of Manchester. Let’s start with his record compared to his biggest rival for the title of best foreign striker - Thierry Henry. Henry always considered himself more of a facilitator than a pure out-and-out striker. Yet his goals-per-match record and shooting accuracy are higher than Aguero. Aguero will finish with more goals but has played in more games and over a longer period than Henry. Heading was never a strength of Henry's but despite being only 5ft 8in, Aguero has an impressive 18 goals with his head compared to just six for the former Arsenal player. Goals per game is arguably the statistic that provides the clearest illustration of how good a striker is. The top eight strikers in this list have all scored at least 110 league goals and made over 200 appearances. Henry is joint-top with Tottenham's Harry Kane on 0.68. Aguero is on his own in third with 0.67. If Aguero was quicker to get up to speed after injury lay-offs it is probable he would have been above Henry and Kane. Aguero's record works out at 109 minutes per goal with a shooting accuracy of 53.69 per cent. In comparison, Kane is currently 123mins and 58.21 respectively. Aguero has 128 goals with his right foot, 34 with his left, 27 from the penalty spot, 160 inside the box and 21 outside the 18-yard area.  It is a testament to Aguero's enduring quality that he adapted his game when Pep Guardiola became manager in 2016 and remained first choice despite competition from Gabriel Jesus. Another major indicator of a striker's prolific side is the number of hat-tricks accrued and this is where Aguero stands out clearly. With 12 trebles to his name, he is ahead by one of Shearer and four clear of Kane, who has eight. Shearer had held the record for a decade before Aguero overtook him with three goals in the 6-1 thrashing of Aston Villa in January 2020. The biggest threat to Aguero's record is Kane, who, provided he stays in England, will certainly run him close. Aguero can also boast scoring four goals in a game on two occasions and five in a 6-1 win over Newcastle in October 2015. Nine of Aguero's hat-tricks have come at the Etihad and six were scored when City had put the same number past their opponent. Invariably, when City battered the opposition, Aguero was there doing most of the damage. As it stands, Aguero is on 181 goals. If he's fit and selected by Guardiola, Aguero is capable of surpassing Cole for third place, especially with games against Crystal Palace, Newcastle and Brighton to come. Aguero has a combined 20 goals against those three teams with a staggering 15 coming against Newcastle.  Among foreign players, Aguero is at the top of the tree with nobody likely to pass him for the foreseeable future. Mohamed Salah (92) and Sadio Mane (91) are the closest active Premier League players to Aguero while Romelu Lukaku (113) could chase him down if he returns to English football in the near future. Aguero's most memorable goal will forever be his stoppage-time strike against QPR which is probably the most important in Premier League history. If he fails to scores, does City's quest for domination get derailed? On the City website, there is a 30-minute compilation of 180 of Aguero's 181 league goals. He started with a brace against Swansea and rarely slowed down, scoring every type of goal you can think of. Quite simply, Aguero has been the deadliest marksmen in Premier League history.

The memories will be flowing tomorrow. It may be 48 years on, but the clown of a goalkeeper, the fruitless pressure, the era-ending aftermath, will all be recalled at length. Yes, England are playing Poland once again in a World Cup qualifier. And never mind that in the 15 meetings since that fateful 1-1 draw, England have not lost to them. Because of that traumatic October evening at Wembley in 1973, the Poles have invariably been cast as the Three Lions’ bogey team. That is what failure does for football fans: it lingers in the collective memory as prominently as victory. But for all the forensic scrutiny of Jan Tomaszewski’s goalkeeping prowess, or Kevin Hector’s last-minute header being hacked off the line, or Norman Hunter’s face as he trooped off the pitch at the final whistle, there is something about that 1973 match that has been largely forgotten in the modern era: back then, there was proper jeopardy involved in World Cup qualification. Over the years since, for the larger footballing nations, the process has become so straightforward as to be almost foolproof. Almost foolproof: as Holland and Italy in 2018, not to mention Graham Taylor’s England in 1994, proved, even a system established to be a ceremonial invitation can be compromised by incompetence. But, back in 1973, getting to the finals was a proper challenge. Uefa’s qualification Group Five consisted of just three teams: England, Wales and Poland. Only the winner progressed; there were no play-offs, no safety net, second place was an irrelevance. It was all or nothing, win or bust. It meant every match mattered, every match had consequence. What is more, there were not very many of them. Alf Ramsey only had to negotiate four games spread across a year; this month,  . Back then, there was value in rarity. And while many a football fan will regard tomorrow’s encounter as a pointless interruption to their club’s league campaign, in 1973 the whole nation held its breath (apart from those of Scottish inclination who were barely able to suppress their laughter). The trepidation was understandable: after losing away in Poland and drawing at home with Wales, England’s chances as they approached their final fixture were already teetering on the brink. There was a real chance that, for the first time since they had condescended to participate, England might not be going to a World Cup. Four years later, it was even more tricky. This time in a four-team group, to get to Argentina, England had to better Italy. They ended up with the same number of points, but failed to head west on goal difference. Over the years since, driven by a Fifa always keen to squeeze its assets until the pips squeak, the finals have been expanded (in 2018 Uefa sent 14 national teams to Russia, in 1974 it was but nine) and the process of getting there eased to ensure the countries delivering big television audiences are as good as certain to be involved. But making it easier has significant repercussions, not least on the meaning of a competition. Since the last-gasp goalless draw in Rome that ensured participation in France 1998, England’s qualification to subsequent World Cups has been almost entirely bereft of drama, a procession of gimmes that have lingered in the collective memory about as long as a goldfish’s circuit of their bowl sticks in theirs. All rarity value has been expunged. Worse, the system has done little to hone the team in preparation for the finals themselves. Ahead of the 2010 tournament, for instance, England strolled through, winning nine of their 10 qualifiers, before stinking out the finals. After knocking out England in 1973, in contrast, a battle-hardened Poland made it to the semi-final of the tournament the following summer, even beating Brazil in the third place play-off. It was their finest World Cup performance. So, when we look back at what happened that fateful October night at Wembley 48 years ago, the nostalgia is infused with a memory of a time when such encounters carried weight. Tomorrow, in truth, is just another game.

heading: Gareth Southgate's 43 England debuts: triumphs, disasters, future Pointless answers
subheading: England have changed dramatically since 2016, but how many new players have made a difference?
author: Thom Gibbs,
article: Roy Hodgson’s final  line-up is a team from a different time. His starting XI for the defeat to Iceland at Euro 2016 was as follows: Joe Hart; Kyle Walker, Gary Cahill, Chris Smalling, Danny Rose; Dele Alli, Eric Dier, Wayne Rooney; Daniel Sturridge, Harry Kane, Raheem Sterling. Despite Gareth Southgate’s nicest revolution ever, all of those players were in the matchday   for his first game against Malta, apart from injury absentees Kane and Sterling.  Now it’s just those two who are likely candidates to start against Croatia on 13 June, an indication of just how much has changed for England under Southgate. He has given debuts to 43 players since taking the job, with most of his experimentation taking place at centre back and in attacking midfield: There is arguably a lack of good options for the former, necessitating some trial and error. In the latter position he has more than he knows what to do with. The England manager has stressed that it should be tough to earn an England cap, but even tougher to lose your place in the squad if you perform well. His loyalty to his World Cup cohort has been clear, sticking with some despite uneven club form.  The boys of '18 lead the way for most caps by Southgate’s debutants, but it’s the quartet of Sancho, Mount, Rice and Chilwell below them which demonstrate how well the new intake has been blooded. How well have Southgate’s picks worked out? We have divided the debutants into five categories, and speculated about who could be added to the list next. only made his debut last year and has just five appearances to date, but barring a dramatic loss of form or   he will have a place in the England squad for as long as he wants it. Pep Guardiola brought the midfielder into the limelight with extreme care and Southgate has played his part too. Should be a mainstay for years to come.  and  were two of the emerging stars from the suddenly lovable England team of 2018. Maguire has recovered from a shaky start to this season and looks a likely pick at centre back for the medium term. With 31 caps under Southgate, no debutant has played more for his manager. Pickford’s status as number one is less assured but Southgate rewards performances for England above all, and the Everton keeper’s domestic ricks have been largely absent when playing for his country.  Southgate gave 10 players their first chance for England in 2018, and none of that group have won as many caps  , with 18 to date. He is pushing hard for a place in the team, and has the look of a useful surprise-start option when others have tired for the final Euros group game.  and   made their debuts six months apart as recently as 2019, both could start in the first game at the Euros. Did you know they’re good friends? Someone should write an article...  was Southgate’s first debutant, he started against Malta in 2016 and was a key player during the World Cup. Went quiet for Manchester United in the years that followed but has impressed at West Ham and Southgate has stuck by his man.   is another beneficiary of the manager’s loyalty. Has recovered his form at Atletico Madrid after a tricky end to his time at Spurs, and that’s before mentioning his betting ban. Superb at the World Cup, and looks to have a guaranteed place in the Euros squad.  On the other flank   is in with a shout of starting at left-back. Has played more than 1,000 minutes since his debut against Switzerland in 2018, only five players have more.  single-handedly makes Aston Villa appointment television but it may not be enough to make Southgate’s starting XI. Clamour from Birmingham alone should secure his space in the squad, but one of the highly talented attacking coterie is going to end up heartbroken. Would be harsh on , but perhaps his youth may be the deciding factor when it comes to the tricky point of finalising a 23 for the Euros? Slightly surprisingly  is the joint top-scorer among Southgate’s debutants with four. Two came against San Marino last week. Mason Mount and Jesse Lingard share his top spot  made his debut in pre-World Cup warm-up against Costa Rica,  ’s came in November against Ireland. They are the likely back-ups to Pickford barring injury. ’s injury means he is unlikely to feature again for England until September’s resumption of World Cup qualifiers.   and   are able deputies at centre back in his absence.   is very good at free kicks.  Several here who are in contention for the Euros squad, and certainly the World Cup campaign that follows.   has been a steady presence in midfield during his six caps to date and has the class to stake a claim.  has a good chance of starting at right-back, the biggest toss-up position in Southgate’s starting XI.  is ahead of  in the current pecking order, both highly talented players who unfortunately may be watching this summer’s football on TV with the rest of us. Leicester’s   has not been used since against Wales in October last year but may get another go after the Euros. Chelsea centre back   is stuck on one cap for now, but his current loan spell at AC Milan makes him an intriguing option at centre back for the future.  Jury decidedly out on the two debutants from last week’s game against San Marino, although you’d probably predict a brighter England future for third-youngest debutant   than Aston Villa’s man in form  .    seems increasingly likely to miss out on the squad this summer, in what you would hope is an odd footnote in an otherwise outstanding career. Southgate picked him early, taking him to the World Cup, so there is no suggestion he doesn’t fancy him. The rest may do him good.   and   are in the dreaded mid-twenties of any ranking of potential England squads. Both solid options, both likely to miss the cut for the Euros.  ’s stock has fallen this season after flourishing in the optimistic youth revolution days of early-Lampard as Chelsea manager.   is a rare bright spot for Newcastle and has four caps under Southgate, but has not featured since 2019.  and   have had senior minutes, but both are currently with the Under-21s at their European Championships. Southgate rates   but has not used him since 2018. Has impressed during Fulham’s semi-renaissance but may need to leave Chelsea permanently this summer to stake a stronger claim for the national team.    and   fit the category of fans’ favourites who ‘should play for England’ but find themselves behind in respective positional pecking orders. Both have a cap each, both in the weird Wayne Rooney farewell game of November 2018 against the USA. Tough to see either adding to that collection soon. One cap and just one minute of action in an England shirt to date for  , he came on in injury time during the dramatic Nations League win over Spain at Wembley. Watford midfielder hasn’t featured since, and after one cap each nor have  ,  ,  , and  .  has played for Southgate three times, but not since Lithuania in October 2017. Twice-capped   is an excellent future pick for players capped under Southgate should it ever come up as a round on Pointless.  seemed close to a call-up before this international break and will surely get his chance after the Euros if he maintains his current form with Leeds. Seems surprising that   has yet to feature for the senior team. He’s 23 so time is on his side, the fact England could field an entire XI of decent right-backs is less positive news. Leicester’s  could be part of that team, his ability to do a job on the other side could make him a useful squad member. Brighton's  fits a team in search of ball-playing central defenders and could be a more than capable understudy to John Stones.  West Brom keeper   is in the current squad and yet to get on the pitch. That is unlikely to change until after the Euros barring an unlikely series of goalkeeper injury disasters. Don’t let Nick Pope even look at a  . Among the England Under 21 squad currently failing to cover itself in glory in Slovenia   looks a safe bet for a call-up within the next year. Crystal Palace’s   has huge potential but must join a long queue of gifted attacking players.  We are legally obliged to mention that Barcelona were interested in   of Norwich, promotion into the Premier League beckons for him and he gives Southgate yet another option at right-back. Liverpool’s   and Tottenham’s   also have the look of future call-ups.  Getting younger still, one Englishman playing abroad who may be worth remembering is winger   at Juventus. A Chelsea youth product showing enormous promise who was born in the year 2003. Terrifying.

heading: The inside story of 'Aguerrooooo', the Premier League's greatest moment - by the players and fans who were there
subheading: It was a defining moment in Premier League history, but what was it really like for players, fans and commentators on a balmy May 13, 2012?
author: Telegraph Sport
article: It was the final day of the 2012 Premier League season and the maths was clear:   - who were themselves locked in a desperate struggle for survival with Bolton Wanderers - would be enough to win them their first league title since 1968. Anything else, and Manchester United would claim another championship with victory at mid-table Sunderland. Here's how the drama unfolded as described by those who were there...

heading: Revealed: The true cost of watching sport in 2021
subheading: Big events are now split across 16 different platforms in the UK - with 13 of those requiring separate regular payment packages
author: Tom Morgan,
article: Sports fans could find themselves paying out in excess of £150 per month on TV subscriptions alone during our great summer of sport. The big events are now split across 16 different broadcast platforms in the UK for the first time, with 13 of those requiring separate regular payment packages, including the TV licence. The arrival of Discovery+ and its new Netflix-style platform which will screen the Olympics and   adds to the most diverse - and potentially most costly - choice for the armchair spectator. For the football enthusiast this spring, viewers would need an iFollow account to watch the crescendo of the EFL season, Sky, BT and Amazon for the Premier League, BT for the Champions League and a separate Premier Sports account for La Liga. And it gets even more complicated for our great sporting summer. While   and Euro 2020 will be on free-to-air, Discovery+ is aiming to draw viewers away from the BBC by promising to show every minute of the Olympics. And then there's  . BT and Sky will both lay claim to the fight due to respective relationships with either boxers. The fight will either be shown on both box office channels simultaneously or be split between the two over the two-fight deal. After a year in which everyone has been forced to stay at home for their sport, here, in a worst-case scenario, is how the charges will add up this summer: All 11 channels, £39 a month (18-month contract) All 11 channels with BT Sport, £52 a month (18-month contract) All channels, £25 a month (monthly pass, no upfront costs) All channels plus BoxNation, £15 a month (24-month contract) All channels plus BoxNation and all Sky Sports channels from the NOW TV Sky Sports Pass, £40 a month (24-month contract) Long gone are the days where you could get your live sporting fix in one place by settling down to an afternoon of Grandstand. Instead, the explosion in popularity of streaming services and subscription-only brands have led to a whole new level of channel hopping. Here is a sport-by-sport breakdown of where you can find sport on TV as it stands:

heading: The proposal threatening to condemn London's homes to darkness
subheading: A consultation is currently underway which could reduce the amount of light builders must allow into newly constructed properties
author: Ben Gartside
article: After a year of rolling lockdowns and shuttered offices, light and airy housing has never been more important to Britain’s legions of city dwellers. Alongside the old staples of a lively local high street, good pub and short commute, a new box has been added to typical home-hunter’s checklist – how much sun their property lets in. But the demand for natural light is threatening to put occupiers at odds with developers at a time when space is at a premium and   is seen as essential to solve the country’s housing crisis. In London, a consultation launched by mayor Sadiq Khan includes a possible reduction in a key measure of how much light builders must allow into their properties, the so-called vertical sky component. “There’s a bit of a battle going on,” says lighting consultant Paul Littlefair. “Obviously, you have developers who want to build bigger and bigger and have buildings that restrict more light. And obviously from a point of view of providing housing in London, you need all this extra housing. “But on the other hand, [you have] existing residents who need daylight and want to retain the daylight they currently have.” The vertical sky component calculates the angle of light entering through a window and is meant to prevent dingy houses from getting built. It is part of planning code and must be taken into account by developers along with other environmental measures. Campaigners argue the changes proposed in the consultation could condemn thousands of families to perpetual semi-darkness. They say that the changes will significantly cut how much light enters individual rooms and point out that being cut off from the sun can harm occupiers’ physical and mental health. “The links between daylight and both physical and mental health are very well established,” says planning activist George Turner. “After a year of being locked down in our homes, I think we can all appreciate the importance of having access to adequate daylight. “Daylight standards do not stop new development, they stop bad development. There is no reason why competent architects can’t design new buildings that protect the living conditions of neighbours.” The row over daylight is already causing a headache for ministers. Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick is poised to rule on a £500m project at 8 Albert Embankment, a London Fire Brigade site being developed into 443 homes which builder U+I says will create 1,200 new jobs. Researchers at the Building Research Establishment (BRE) have warned that 424 properties would fall below its recommended daylight standards as new buildings cut off the views from existing ones, including accommodation for disabled people in the ground floor of a nearby block of flats, and Turner is leading a bid to protect neighbours’ rights. A spokesman for U+I defended the development, saying the benefits outweighed the costs.
